38181811.review:
This game is so much better than I expected, and I'm so glad I picked up the developer bundle. LiEat was the first game from Miwashiba that I'd ever played, and I was absolutely amazed.

First off, the soundtrack is gorgeous. It makes the story feel more alive than it already is. Each chapter has its own music too, it's not just one soundtrack being filled into every storyline. As the game advertises the OST comes with the game, which makes it all the more worth it. Not just the sound, but the art style is gorgeous as well. Not so much as the main world, but the CGs during certain cutscenes. Some of them you can see above, in the game's featured videos/screenshots. I absolutely love the art style and how well it fits into the game.

But besides the soundtrack, the story is downright amazing. The game is split into three distinct chapters. The storylines don't fully connect, as they take place in completely different locations, but they do tie together and are told chronologically, so I would highly recommend playing them in order. Each chapter takes about an hour and a half to two hours to complete, depending on how fast of a reader you are, or if you read the content at all. 

The entire storyline focuses around Efina, the Lie-Eating Dragon and her "papa", who goes by Leo/Hal/Sid in the three chapters. Along they way they solve three separate mysteries, while learning about Efina and her power, and where she came from. There's a heavy emphasis on the story's tales of dragons, along with liars and how they relate to the world. There's a large portion of the story that's either downright adorable, or so intense that you feel strongly for what is going on. For a cute game, it also has it's serious points, mostly to do with liars and caring for loved ones. It's charming in a way that works, even for a simple and short RPG.

The only thing I would even remotely have against this game is how small the world is. There's only one area and a couple side areas to explore. I feel like this game makes it work rather well. All the story is in one spot, which makes it straight forward and you aren't getting lost or turned around often. For the story requiring you to do things in a certain order, I feel like this is more of a good thing than a bad thing, but if you enjoy exploring a massive world, you may not enjoy how small the map is.

For you achievement hunters out there, some of them are more difficult to find as they require you to interact with the world. Reading the info on the achievement should give you a straight-forward idea of how to get them all, though they're all chapter specific, so you have to know where to look for what. In my first runs of each chapter I got probably half of them, or a little over half.

This game is one of my new favorites, and I highly recommend it to anyone who enjoys RPGs and fantasy. This game deserves so much more attention than it's getting.

37915061.review:
Prosta i dosyć krótka gierka podzielona na 3 samodzielne rozdziały. Posiada klimat historii drogi oraz lekkiego kryminału. Podróżując z naszymi bohaterami poznajemy pewien wycinek dosyć ciekawego świata, powoli odkrywając jego tajniki jaki i tajemnice skrywane przez postacie (te główne, jak i te napotkane na naszej drodze). I właśnie siłą opowieści w tej gierce są właśnie bohaterowie, ich relacje, ich rozwój i tajemnice (i kłamstwa z nimi związane). Sam gameplay jest znikomy i jest w sumie tłem do opowieści, mamy oczywiście proste łamigłówki, walki rodem z jrpg-ów i końcowe walki z bosami, jednak nic bardzo wymagającego tu nie znajdziemy. 

Na szczególną uwagę zasługuję tu oprawa audio wizualna, świetnie podkreśla klimat, jest spójna i po prostu cudowna. Krótkie wspaniale zaanimowane filmiki (nawiązujące do wydarzeń w trakcie rozgrywki), nieoczywiste kadry (odbicia w oku, perspektywa zza ściąganej maski, cienie niedosłownych wydarzeń). A całość domyka wyśmienita muzyka.

Gra zapewne nie każdemu podpasuje (np. z powodu nikłego gameplay-u), jednak z całą pewnością mogę polecić ją każdemu komu spodobał się klimat gier takich jak "Ib", lub chcą sobie pograć w międzyczasie w krótką gierkę z dobrym morałem w ładnej oprawie.

36695381.review:
I'm going to recommend it because it only costs three dollars and takes about 3 hours to finish, which sounds like decent value to me.
I've got more hours than that because I left it open and forgot.

*Going to rant about some negative stuff first:*

There is fuck all gameplay beyond walking around and then spamming your way through most battles so long as you pick up all the items(of which there are very few) 
The story is rather predictable, very linear and lacks any real progression across the chapters. You start from scratch and almost all the characters you meet are new. The only real development is between theo and efina but even that is quite minor.
There are systems for leveling up and earning gold, but they hardly matter given there are no options or stores, all it means is that you don't have access to all your abilities at the start, which hardly matters given how easy combat is throughout.
Equipment exists only as linear upgrades with minor flavour text acquired just by rummaging through (mostly the inhabited) rooms/areas of the game.
No replayablity beyond the necessity to fail to get all the achievements.
The game lacks some details too, there are no names during dialogue, no alerts for the consumables given during conversation and doors are poorly indicated when not above your character (this was a minor issue during the second chapter when I did not immediately realize there were side rooms). 

Redeeming qualities are the cute characters with decent designs and fairly enjoyable dialogue/interactions. Sprites are good, profiles lack clarity and don't show much facial detail due to their scope but are otherwise good and the animated clips/cgs are done well enough but for some reason the animated bits look like they're being played in 240p

36647720.review:
I was not gonna recommend it, but after playing the 3rd game, I changed my mind.

LiEat is 3 mini-RPGs where you control 2 characters, a guy who uses knives and a small dragon girl who has a unique power, eating lies. The game consists in going through a town (which is not very big, consist in 1 to ~5 screens and houses/rooms), talking to people and eat the lies that materialize around them to uncover the truth.

I did not like this game much, but it has its charm. Mostly, I didn't like the game's direction. It had great potential, good artistic skills, and great musical skills.
The art is very confusing. It's close to impossible to tell which character is a guy or a girl, and it's hard to identify their dialogue-sprite with their in-game sprite, the sprites just don't have enough detail. Also, there is a weird drawing around the dialogue-sprite which is confusing, and at the beginning, I thought it was part of the sprite where the character had some weird wings or something.
As for the music, there are sudden changes between dead silence and cheery music in a dark atmosphere. Most of the time the music did not feel quite right.
The thing I liked the most from the game, is the battle theme. At first, you fight small lies which take seconds to defeat, but later in the game, you face a big deformed lie, which takes some time, and that was when for the first time I heard the whole battle theme, and woah, it's a masterpiece. The piano is fantastic, it really gets you pumped up to fight.
I said this game had a lot of potential, mostly because of the following reasons:
Bad directing, too short, and boring gameplay.
The combat is really easy, it's almost impossible to get a game over. You always equip the same items in all 3 games, and there is 0 strategy. I know the game tries to focus mainly on the story, but a more challenging combat would have been nice too.

Something that surprised me, was that the game had animated cutscenes, which look nice, but too short.

As for the story... it was ok, it's a matter of taste, really. I liked the "couple" Efi and Leo, but I wish there was a bit more interaction between them. Leo always seemed way too distant from Efi, which made me kind of sad. I would have enjoyed a bit more "romanticism" or affection between them.
The 3rd game has the best story, in my opinion, that is why I decided to give a recommended vote instead of a non-recommended.

It's very cheap, but I'd suggest to put it on your wishlist and wait for a sale. I'd also suggest to not listen to the soundtrack before you play it (especially the battle theme) since it's great and it's better to hear it while you're inside the story.

Even with this game having "Overwhelmingly Positive" reviews, it was still better than I thought it'd be.

LiEat is a game where you follow the adventures of a con man and a lie-eating dragon as they visit different towns and help out the people they meet. Now, the combat is really easy and the mysteries/puzzles can be pretty easy to figure out. But, the story and characters are what keeps me interested. The story and characters are great! I especially like our main duo, their relationship is really cute. The art and animation is also amazing and very cute.  

The game is separted into three parts, and since the game is $3, that's essentially $1 per part. Well, I definitely think that price is worth it! I highly recommend this game if you're looking for something cute and sweet with interesting characters and a great story. :)

36460469.review:
[h1]小萝莉很萌，很甜的一个游戏[/h1]
类RPG的视觉小说？
大概就是一个欺诈师和一条龙浪迹天涯的故事
音乐有点海底囚人的风格，个人很喜欢这种比较童话一点的音乐，当然质量肯定是不错的
游戏方式非常简单，一个场景到处找人就行了，我觉得卡关可能性不大
前两部分难度几乎没有，一般小怪随便打打，大怪萝莉用火清，BOSS飞刀3连非常简单。而且到后面BOSS打几乎不掉血，如果不是有在旁边看这个选项，做BE成就的难度才是最大的。第三部分稍微加入了一点练级元素和影响结局的练度。
像素画风跟日式RPG如出一辙，小动画很不错

NPC人物塑造
我知道很大程度上受到游戏流程的制约，但明显制作组的眼光一开始也没有放在NPC上，主要就是Teo和Efi，说实话第一部分通关后我连BOSS和妹妹的了解几乎为零，后两部分还好一点了，本来是事件中心的角色只用简单的笔墨勾画，是不是有点本末倒置了？

原价15打折10元，少吃一碗面条都有了，原价买都不亏
背景改一下吧，画成小动画那种风格都可以，这几张完全无法煽动合卡的情绪....

36427282.review:
詐欺師の青年と嘘を食べるドラゴン少女が、色々な事件の中で自分自身について知っていくお話です。
無料版もあるみたいですが、実績やバッジ等が有るうえにセール中だったのでsteamで購入。
かわいらしいドットと絵、不思議でちょっとダークな世界観に引き込まれ没入しました
エフィーナちゃんかわいい。
ゲーム性についてですが、他の方もおっしゃっている通りRPGといっても戦闘ばかりでなく、謎解きや会話がメインになってきます。
ボリュームもそこまで多いわけではなく、色々ゆっくり調べて回ったりしていても実績コンプも含めて８時間ほどで終わりました。
それでもストーリーは内容が濃く、考えさせられる部分も多かったですし、元がフリーゲームであることも考えると凄い完成度です。
絵柄やドットが気になった人、kawaiiが好きな人は買って損しないと思います

36259022.review:
"Lies are just a messy way of covering up for your past."

LiEat is a simple, turn-based JRPG centered around a traveling conman of many names and his faithful "sidekick", Efina. However Efina is not your average young girl...she instead is a dragon, blessed with the power to see and devour the lies of others. An interesting premise for sure, especially considering her choice in a traveling partner. I wasn't expecting much out of LiEat, but I was pleasantly surprised.

The game is broken down into three acts (LiEat I, LiEat II, and Lieat III). Each act involves the conman main character taking on a different name and getting involved in a few messy situations in different locations, from a sleepy town to a fancy resort. In the process of doing so, the conman's unfortunate past is slowly revealed and Efina grows from a naive newborn dragon into a capable young girl (although she's still pretty naive). LiEat I and II are really just build-up for the finale in the third act, in which you can get a bad, neutral, or good ending depending on your choices during the third act. The story, while simple, is still interesting enough and is able to resolve itself happily in the end (or tragically, if you got the neutral ending). Each act takes around an hour to complete, and it's one of the most entertaining games I've played that takes under five hours to complete.

The combat is in a simple turn-based format. I'm not sure how the turn order entirely works, as it seems like the enemies almost always took the first turn, which was mildly annoying as healing items do not take priority. Each character has a few different skills to use, most of them dealing single-target or AoE damage. The format is extremely simple and does not take long to pick up on. Throughout the games, if you are diligent in searching around the world, you can find some nice new gear, including legendary weapons which allow you to one-shot most enemies and make boss fights absolutely trivial. However, without a guide, these weapons are rather difficult to find. Quite frankly, they break the game, so it might be better not to hunt for them.

The OST, while nothing special, does what it needs to do to evoke certain emotions in certain scenes. In particular, the final boss fight for the first act is something that stands out as one of the better tracks in the game. It's nothing to write home about, but certainly above-average for a cheap Steam JRPG.

LiEat is a game that ends up being a lot better than it first lets on, and if it goes on sale, I would recommend picking it up. It certainly makes for an interesting evening, if absolutely nothing else, and...come on. Efina is adorable. How can you say no to that face?

35782917.review:
Preface: I’ve only played through Chapter 1 completely but if my opinion of the game as whole changes, I’ll change my review to reflect that.

Overview:
Visuals: 10/10
Gameplay: 8/10
Sounds: 8/10
Story: 7/10
Overall: 9/10

Lieat is one of the most refreshing indie rpgs I’ve had the pleasure of experiencing. The first area where this game succeeds in its world building. The world and its structure are reasonable and creative. Basically, there are humans and monsters, most monsters are uncommon and/or urban legend but dragons are the exceptions given that they’re born near humans (each dragon, born with their own unique power). Our heroine is a dragon that was born with the ability to sense and eat lies. Our hero (if you can call him that, he’s kind of a jerk), Is a human that is something of an information broker which we can assume is a popular trade in this world, given that at least ⅓ of the characters you meet in the first chapter are information brokers too. In chapter 1, the narrative comes off headstrong in that it does a weak job of immersing the player into this world and suffers from an issue that plagues most ametuer narratives; world building is eagerly thrown at the player left and right without pacing or tact. Between each plot point are moments that seem purposely designated for combat.

The combat doesn’t do much to break from a traditional turn-based system but it doesn’t do anything to fail that tradition either. The combat never drags on, the enemies are diverse enough, and the battle system is simple: attack, skill, item. This makes it easy to keep fighting  I wish there was a “defend” option for the player because sometimes the quantity of enemies is overwhelming (and the enemies can defend) but I can understand leaving it out because every turn spent defending is one that you could’ve spent doing something offensive and that’s what this game’s combat is about: supplementing the story through quick and simple turn based mechanics. This is executed perfectly, better than the turn-based combat in a lot of big budget titles. Combat is coupled with satisfactory animation and great music.

Prior to finishing the first chapter, I was ready to dismiss the game’s audio as satisfactory at best but the post chapter ‘theater room’ (my term, not theirs) was an excellent way to emphasize the quality art and music this game had to offer. In the center of the room is a music box-esque system that lets you play the tracks from throughout the chapter with a twist. Each track can be sped up or slowed down using on screen sliders. Every track sounds just as good at any speed and there are plenty of tracks to play around with. I would have been satisfied with this but the theater room has a far wall with different art from the chapter.

This is a great opportunity to appreciate the well crafted aesthetic of the game. The chibi anime art style is complemented with a mix of pixel-vintage-theatre visuals which serve to reflect the narrative of the game perfectly and contributes further to the fantasy theme. The theater room was so impressive and well done, it made me wish every rpg had something like it. Opportunities to reflect on what a game does well (in this case, the art and music) leave the player with a more memorable experience overall.

It might seem from my review that Lieat is an average game that hits a few good points but it’s execution confirms the opposite. It’s rare that a game does simple things the right way with satisfying results like Lieat. In a time where the rpg genre is oversaturated with lengthy cutscenes, over-the-top combat that tries to reinvent the wheel, long/drawn out narratives, Lieat is a breath of fresh air that I recommend to any fan of the genre.

35660683.review:
LiEat is a beautiful game, the first location you visit has a very eerie atmosphere to it. The small town slowly becomes darker and darker as night approaches. I especially love that they give new character portraits when you are playing later chapters, you can see some characters have grown, indicating time has passed. Short little animations and CG scenes also play out during parts of the game, a very nice touch to give the game some life out of pixel rpg sprites.

The music has a really gentle tone, but it is also used to build a sense of unease during certain events. It's not used carelessly either, sometimes no music plays and you can feel something bad happened. It's good stuff, I don't usually complement the music in reviews but I really should for this one.

The writing... The characters are often times are very humourous, I liked almost all the main and supporting characters. I can't put into words how much I enjoy the dialogue in this game. Talking to a NPC multiple times sometimes trigger dialogue that is both interesting and adds to the lore of this game. My favourite characters have to be the Captain of the force and the main character Efina, both dragons with interesting abilities. Conversations between them give some context to the captain's backstory and even a possible reason why Dragons with unique abilities are born.

Buying LiEat gives you 3 games, I highly recommend finishing each of the games in a single sitting. As stopping midway during one of the games can be immersion breaking and ruin the atmosphere. They aren't very long, about 1-3 hours for each game. I do not regret this purchase and I urge anyone who wants a great time to give it a shot. 

If I can name only one thing to convince you to buy the game, it's the writing. I'm a writer in training and I wish I was as half as good as writing the dialogue in this game. The gameplay really doesn't focus on combat much, which I feel is a good thing. It keeps the pace going and is more focused on character interactions instead.

[b]Chapter 3:[/b] This. Was. Worth. Every. Penny. Idk if I'll ever find a game sweeter than this. <3
 
---

For seriously, I am head over heels for LiEat and Miwashiba. This game is an RPG featuring multiple endings and a primary focus on dialogue, story, kawaii-factor, and character building. There is a battle system, but it is meant to be supplemental and not distract from the furthering the plot, so don't expect much brain-bending or difficulty.
Please pick this up! Its utter charm and interesting play-elements are sure to win you over ~

35249985.review:
LiEat is not a game for people who are looking for a challanging RPG game -- it is by no means difficult or try to focus in that department...

But only because it doesn't have to.

All three LiEat games are mostly exploration and story focused, being rather heavy on dialouge and story. All three games are proper sequels to the previous(well, there WERE a few towns skipped but that's because nothing really important happened there).

The story is of a man who's present is riddled to the brim with lies and a dragon girl born from his wishes, who can eat lies. The games sum the story up, as if you were watching an anime: it keeps it short, semi-well detailed yet entertaining. Personally, I enjoyed the twists the stories had each time, with new, unfamiliar faces with each of their own backgrounds and reasons for their actions.

The sprite work is pretty fancy and smooth to the eyes, yet sometimes very very distracting(for example the alley way in 1, that took some time to find!), but over all pretty pleasurable to look at. Character design focuses very heavily on making every character look as adorable as they could possibly make them.

...Thing is, that's where LiEat begins to fall short.

The gameplay is rather dull, as there's not much thinking to be done during combat. The moves are very straight forward and often you just need to spam them to win basically any battle. Exploration is often limited or pointless, and it's very easy to get confused. There aren't many places to explore and there aren't anything worthwile to find.

Pros:
+Endearing spritework, pleasurable to look at
+Story is indeed, pretty good and the world keeps it as consistent as it could.
+Efi. That's all.
+The price is rather low for such an experience.

Mixed:
+/- It doesn't focus on music too well. Sure, it gets the job fairly done, but it is, still, just midis.
+/- Characters often don't return, some for good, some for bad.

Cons:
-Combat isn't exciting, rather dull and repetitive.
-Exploration is stuck to a maximum of 9 maps, very few things to find.
-The games aren't really that difficult, as they serve little to no challenge.
-All three games combined are really really short, summing up to 4 hours.

Over all, I do recommend LiEat. Why? It aims to be a story telling RPG game, and it does that job well, and I absolutely adore that. The world is pretty well built together, makes you wonder on and on about what could, what would and what is in that universe. Characters are memorable and adorable and the spritework does it's best to reflect that.

If you did like LiEat(especially part 3), I'd reccomend you check out DSP(Deep Sea Prisoner)'s works. They being The Gray Garden, Mogeko Castle and Wadanohara and the Great Blue Sea. These are all story driven games with fun characters where the story does end up getting really eerie near the end. Funnily enough, vgperson is the very same person that translated their works and LiEat! While I do recommend these, be vary DSP's works have an intense amount of gore, controversial subjects and other triggering events to some.

While I do recommend these, I still do recommend you to check out LiEat first if you want something way less eerie, cute and memorable.

35146632.review:
[h1] 欺诈师与以谎言为食的龙：虚伪的善意，善意的虚伪	[/h1]

《LiEat》作为一款像素风格的AVG游戏，由三个相对独立但又有些许关联的小故事构成，总流程大概在3,4个小时左右。

值得一提的是，通关之后因为对游戏中的动画和CG图很感兴趣，所以在网上搜索了一下本作游戏的画师资料，结果发现担任游戏制作、编剧、音乐与插画的是同一个人：日本著名的画师△○□×（也叫miwasiba太太），实在是个很厉害的人！游戏本身在游戏主页上也是免费公开的，steam版的购买更多的是赞助性质的。

男主角是一位帅气的欺诈师，通过搜集并贩卖情报为生，每到一个城市都会乔装改名，满口谎言却心地善良。

女主角是一位可爱的龙族萝莉，以不明原因突然出现在男主面前，能够嗅到谎言的气息并以谎言为食，但却无法识破男主角的谎言。

两个身世成谜的人，三个不同城市的冒险...

[h1] 并不那么复杂的剧情，有时却更吸引人	[/h1]

如之前所说，游戏分为三个章节，讲述了三段不同城市的冒险经历。三段故事相对独立，但它们之间又有着些许关联，都讲述了一个道理：为了守护某些事物的谎言，即使是善意的谎言，到最后也可能什么都保护不了。游戏剧情的表现非常出色，不会过分煽情，情感表现的恰到好处，剧情中间穿插的一些角色互动也很甜，建议与每个NPC的对话都不要放过~

游戏的玩法采用的是线性流程，以对话为剧情推动的主体，有一定的解谜元素，辅以简单并适量的回合制战斗。剧情比较紧凑，悬念设计的也很吸引人。战斗部分主要是通过和NPC对话，来分辨说的是真话还是谎言，最后通过战斗消灭谎言。每个章节都有好结局与坏结局，其中第一章和第三章有HE,BE,NE三种结局。第二章似乎只有HE,BE两种结局，在此不做过多的剧透，留给各位自行探索。

不过在游戏体验上也有一些小小的问题，游戏中一些剧情的触发点并没有明确的对话提示，所以可能会导致短时间的卡关。这时候只需要到处找找转转，或者对对话，应该就能解决。

[h1]怀旧的八位机风格音乐 	[/h1]

游戏中的配乐采用的怀旧的八位机风格，旋律虽然简单但却非常优美动听。游戏中一些紧张的情节，感人的情节，都得益于配乐的优秀使得剧情感染力更强。不得不吹一波miwasiba太太真的是全才啊！另外游戏的OST是随游戏本体附赠的，可以在steam的音乐列表中查找。

[h1] 奇异的世界观，出色的作画	[/h1]

像素风格的游戏画面或多或少都会制约游戏剧情的发挥，但制作人本身作为一名出色的插画师，很好的弥补了《LiEat》像素风格画面的短板。游戏中的世界观非常新奇有趣，每个角色的立绘都个性鲜明，可以说非常的用心。游戏中会根据剧情的推进穿插一些精美的CG图与小动画，因为作者扎实的绘画功底（再吹一波miwasiba太太），使得游戏的表现力得到了很好的发挥！

[h1] 一些提醒与吐槽：	[/h1]

1.游戏中的装备和武器需要通过场景搜索获得，每章的神器都藏在不起眼的角落~

2.游戏每章都有多个结局，所以不想重新打又想体验所有结局的话，勤存档吧。

3.战斗给的金钱到底有个啥用啊！！！

[h1] 小巧而精致的AVG游戏，剧情、配乐、画面表现都属上乘，不容错过的佳作！	[/h1]

没想到通关了这么久以后才来写评测。
首先必须要说，女主太可爱了，然后就是男主也实在是帅气的不行。
不得不说是一部“小巧精致”的佳作，三个章节讲述的也是不一样色彩的故事，千万不要被第一章的一些桥段吓到而放弃啊，这不是恐怖RPG啊喂。通关以后就像是看了很不错的短篇故事一样的感受，即使现在回忆起来也能够有很多画面出现在脑海里面。立体的人物塑造、有趣的世界观设定，以及作为点缀十分可爱的一些小动画。很多元素都在使这个游戏变得更加有意思——或者也可以说，使这个故事更加精彩。
总而言之还是希望有更多人可以过来尝试一下这部作品，如果你不抵触日式像素RPG的话，相信它会给你带来不错的感受。
……不过有些坏结局还是蛮残酷的，有点讨厌呢。

注意：我几个月前玩的时候，中文版只有第二章在垃圾堆里面找糖果的那个成就无法解锁必须进英文版重新拿，不知道现在如何了，供大家参考一下。

The art style was really nice too, going from still pictures to short animations. It's a simple style but because of its semplicity I find it very fitting with the game scenario and ambiance. Keeping this cute almost childish style considering the rather dark story gives it a weird yet interesting effect.
I enjoyed the story even though I found it pretty short, giving little bits of the story here and there throught the three chapters and a big chunk of it at the very end of the third, which was a little overwhelmind in my opinion. I would have liked if the series started from an earlier point, like the moment in which Efina hatches to get a better grasp of the characters personality and the why of everything that is going on little by little instead of getting it all thrown at you at the very end.

It's a very nice game, I surely recommend it but if you're unsure, I would wait until it's on sale for two dollars or less since it's a pretty short game.

[h1]優點[/h1]

[h1]缺點[/h1]
成也劇情、敗也劇情：
獨特的世界觀與人物塑造在1、2代發揮的很好，
但在3代，反而因為前期的劇情難以收束，就在結尾爆炸了，過於簡單粗暴的轉折看的我一肚子火

另外3代的遊戲時長明明會比1、2代都多上許多，但最耗時間的卻是設計不好的解謎
讓我有看某動畫一樣的感覺：12集已經不夠演了，但是編劇麻子依然要給你打上一集棒球。

總之第3代比前兩代差的多，爆炸的劇情折磨我的理智、硬湊的解謎折磨我的耐心、GE的奇怪條件既折磨我的耐心也折磨我的理智。

[h1]結論[/h1]
總之還是推薦的，就是玩3代的時候要有點心理準備

34726004.review:
TL;DR version: a cute bite-sized set of JRPG vignettes. While extremely easy and containing a weirdly-written finale in its third vignette, it's worth sitting through in an afternoon.

[Actual Review]

LiEat is a series of three short JRPGs made by Miwashiba on WOLF RPG Editor, originally released in 2004. It follows a dragon by the name of Efina -- who has the ability to eat lies -- and her conman "papa". Each tale brings them to a new location on a different job, usually where supernatural circumstances are at play.

The story of LiEat is very easy to condense down into what happens within these three chapters as well as the loose worldbuilding connective tissue between each one. Playing each episode in close succession allows these threads to all come through, even if some of the characters end up being filler. The main problems I personally had with the stories as a whole included the shoehorned bad/neutral ends. At best, they came out of nowhere (one of them I actually had to look up a guide to get, simply because you have to go out of your way for it). At worst, they contain questionable writing choices (particularly in the third story in the set). The entire third game feels like a series of padding decisions after a little while, and it all feels like it's a rush job to a neat-on-paper character arc resolution. I still like it, but it definitely felt rushed. What I enjoyed about the story the most, however, was the nature of why people lie, and how that is addressed. The reasons people lie, the consequences when found out, and how one lives with themselves when they tell nothing but lies for a living. It's worth looking at even for that alone, along with the different powers that dragons possess in terms of standard fantasy worldbuilding.

Aesthetically, this game has a distinctive style to it that I greatly appreciate. It feels like a NIS game's typical art style combined with GBA Castlevania in a sense, thrown into WOLF and garbled a bit. It feels like I should be playing it in either 240p or on a handheld, which is not a knock against it. There's a lot of imagination to the character designs in general, even when playing with anime archetypes in design. It's a nod to the good bits of subtle worldbuilding in LiEat, not being afriad to differentiate between what is and is not human.  The soundtrack is pretty alright, too, with some standout variations on the battle theme throughtout and some musical progressions that bring to mind European folk villages; there's a lot of good, tense additions to the atmosphere in the score that I really appreciated.

The gameplay is standard turn-based RPG format. You wander around a standard map, interact with things (you don't have to do moving "puzzles" of any sort until LiEat 3), and then get into battles that spawn on the map (no random encounters here). Battles are the typical Attack/Skill/Item/Nothing system, but I appreciated how quickly it flowed. Every episode has strong weapons you can find on the map, and it makes battles a major breeze to get through. Not much strategy, but given how quickly each game unfolds, it's nice. The exploration in LiEat 3, as explained with the general story of that game, feels like padding more often than not, but it still includes a lot of streamlined elements within battle to make that a lot easier.

Overall, LiEat is an easy but interesting experience. The nature of the release is benefitted by how streamlined it all is, and for as cheap as it often is and how quick of a play it is, it's a worthwhile investment if you enjoy JRPGs.

34645120.review:
Nostalgie, oh süße Nostalgie.

In Miwashibas zweitem Spiel, einer (viel) zu kurzen Trilogie, 'LiEat' werden wir mitten in die Geschichte unserer Protagonisten geworfen. Von Stadt zu Stadt wandert der Lügner mit seiner kleinen Drachendame, die - wie jeder Drache in diese Spiel - nicht nur rar gesät ist, sondern auch aus einem ganz bestimmten Wunsch geboren wurde. Unser Protagonist hatte einen Wunsch, einen starken noch dazu, und wurde mit einem Drachenei entlohnt, das plötzlich auftauchte - wie ironisch also, dass der Lügner einen Drachen bekommt, der Lügen manifestieren und essen kann. Kein Wunder, dass Efina ihn 'Theopants' nennt, nachdem sie seinen realen Namen - den sie erst durch Umwege herausfindet - erfährt. Liar, liar pants on fire - was? (War das nicht auch ein Achievement?)

Zusammenfassend, ohne viel zu spoilern, sei gesagt: Jeder, der ein kurzes Abenteuer für zwischendurch, mit ansehnlichen Farben und Grafiken, sowie ein bisschen Horror in ein freundlicheres Gewand gepackt möchte, der ist - nicht nur durch den Soundtrack der überall sehr sehr gut klingt - herzlich eingelanden, einen Blick in diese komische, magische Welt zu werfen und herauszufinden, was es mit Theobald Leonhearts (da hat die Translation einen Fehler gemacht, weil's nicht LeonHART sondern LeonHEARTS ist) auf sich hat. Lange wird man zwar nicht bleiben, weil das Spiel verdammt kurz ist, aber die 2 Euro ist es auf alle Fälle wert - und dann wünscht man sich mehr, und muss leider herausfinden, dass der Macher nicht auch nur im entferntesten daran denkt, weiterzumachen - schade. (Na ja, bleiben ja noch "1BitHeart", "1BeatHeart" und eventuell "The Faceless Double", nicht?)

34417648.review:
This review is a shortened version of my review published here: nothingnewreviews.wordpress.com/lieat-miwashiba

"LiEat" is a series of three short, simplistic story-driven RPGs with a strong focus on the relationships between the characters and the tension between the two races of the world: humans and dragons. At the same time, while this theme overarches across all three games, "LiEat" doesn't let its main story overtake the story of any individual game.
Before I really begin, I want to clarify that this game will not be for everyone. As a writer myself, I found the story to be lacking and, as a gamer, I found the balance of the game to be even worse. That is not to say this is a bad game, because it isn't... but it does mean you will be less likely to enjoy the game if you focus too much on either aspect of the game. Both parts are equally important and should not be ignored. That said, for the purpose of this review, I will be analyzing the aspects separately.
First, let's discuss the music, which was one of my favorite parts of the game. In all three games, you have interesting, well-composed tracks that fit beautifully not just with the game and the scenes they appear in, but, as actual songs, they also fit well with each other conveying a smooth story-progression through their melodies. While there were a couple songs that felt somewhat generic, the game's composer did an (overall) excellent job at matching the moods and tones that needed to be conveyed.
While there are plenty of parts in the graphic design of the game that feel like a generic RPG Maker game, there are just as many unique design choices. While the interfaces may be plain, they are still functional; and, while the overworld feels initially uninspired, it is very clear there was effort put into making the game feel both familiar and new at the same time. While the overworld is far from original, the real prize is found in the cut-scenes. Just as the monotony of the overworld and the repetitive combat (more on that in just a moment) got to be tiresome, the beautifully stylized cutscenes (and even the stylistic still-frames) appeared, and, with them, a breath of renewed enjoyment in the visual experience of the game would arrive. Finally, we have the character sprites. While most of the enemies look like generic black slimes, each of the actual characters was visually beautiful and had their own unique charm.
I feel "LiEat"'s combat deserves its own discussion... for how overwhelmingly bland and generic it is. In "LiEat", you really only have 2 main enemy types: Lies and Bosses. While each Boss looks unique and different, and while there are different appearaces for the Lies, combat in this game is really just "Stab... Stab... Stab..." with no need to act differently. During my first playthrough of "LiEat I", the game accidentally made my party completely incapable of taking ANY damage from the game's BOSS due to its poor balancing of stats, enemies, and EXP gains. The only thing noteworthy about the combat is the artwork of the bosses and the lack of too many combat animations gives the game a sort of neo-classical sort of charm to it as though it is trying to be reminiscent of older games... otherwise, it's a no-thought-involved cookie cutter system that makes you actually have to try in order to die.
Fortunately, in the overall gameplay, you can avoid most of the sLIEmeS if you want, and I encourage it if you want the game to have an ounce of difficulty, but otherwise, gameplay is almost as simple and generic as combat was... But it worked well with the story and actually felt fitting for the overall feel of the game. Most of the puzzles were exceedingly obvious, but never felt like chores to solve because, unlike many games, the puzzles reward you as you do them with interesting dialogue, access to new areas, and overall story-progression in the moment and not just at the end. While combat was underbalanced, general gameplay was quite well-balanced and well-done. The way gameplay integrated the story into each action of the quests... it was a breath of fresh air. During typical quest completions, I usually don't actually have fun, but that was not so for "LiEat". The fact the story is given to you as opposed to needing to be hunted down was another nice touch. While the game does reward you handsomely for investigating and looking for secrets, it also doesn’t make you need to do any needless hunting in order to find where you need to go next; the game maintains a nice, consistent flow that is only added to by searching and not detracted from, which is something most games try and fail to do.
Finally, we have the (spoiler-free) story. The story is essentially a modern take on classic noir fiction. While the setting may not be black and white, many of the other core elements are there. Overall, the story is fairly predictable if you know the standard tropes and patterns associated with classic noir fiction and if you picked up on the foreshadowing used throughout the games from the very first scene. That said, if you're unfamiliar with the genre, this game can serve as an excellent gateway enabling you to see the charms while still being family-friendly. However, the story did have some issues. To begin with, the story felt shallow from its over-devotion to a central story line over three terribly short games. Generally, maintaining a persistent narrative would be a virtue, not a vice, but it actually worked against “LiEat”. While the writer tried to sprinkle foreshadowing into each game to show what was yet to come, there was still little build-up. The writing was amazing for a children’s game or if it had been a longer series, but for general audiences as it is right now, it would fall flat. The other major problem was the lack of dimension to the characters: only the anti-hero and the "bad cop" (of sorts) had more than one dimension to their personalities. Overall, I still liked the story, but it irritated me how quickly the Chekhov’s Guns went off and how the characters needed more than one game to develop even slightly.
Despite how harshly I criticized “LiEat”, I actually enjoyed the series significantly. I didn’t have to go out of my way to find the story. The game still rewarded me for being curious. The music was great and the cut-scenes were eye-grabbingly beautiful. There really isn’t a reason to outright dislike “LiEat” if you look at it as a whole. While combat was rubbish and the writing weak, it was still enjoyable for as brief as it was. Everything contributed to the series equally. Even if the combat was absolute garbage and even if the writing wasn’t where I would have liked it to be, the way the individual parts of “LiEat” interacted with one another created a beautiful tapestry of a series. My only regret is that “LiEat” was as short as it is and lacks any real replay value, as even a self-imposed “hard-mode” does little to increase the difficulty of the games.
"LiEat" is a beautiful series and may have just become one of my favorites. While it seems odd that I can have so many complaints but still love these games (possibly more than I do some of my childhood classics), "LiEat" had an interesting story, despite not being as fleshed out as it should have been. The music and cut-scenes were amazing. The gameplay, bar the combat, blended well with the narrative and pacing. If you think of a game as being about mostly this or mostly that, don’t spend a cent on this game… but if you can accept the bad qualities of a game because those qualities themselves are actually made better by the other qualities of the game, "LiEat" should be in your Library and thrown to the top of your Queue.
~Sora
Estimated Playtime: ~1 hour to get all achievements via speed-run, thus making my review moot
Taking Time: ~3-5 hours if you let yourself get absorbed into the world
My Rating: 8/10 – worth the $2.99 gamble
Without the Garbage Combat: 9/10 – Not perfect, but definitely great

LiEat est un ensemble de trois jeux acronymes (LiEat I, II, III) où nous suivons l'histoire d'une petite fille, possédant des pouvoirs liés aux Mensonges, et de son "frère". L'histoire est très intéressante, et variée.
Je recommande ce jeu à quiconque aime les petits RPGs plus pour leurs histoire que leurs gameplays.

34336280.review:
LiEat is a three-in-one trilogy mystery RPG series about a young dragon girl capable of materializing and eating lies. 

Pros:
+3 games in 1, totaling to five hours of playtime
+Each game is varied from one another, identical in gameplay (aside from some parts in the third game) but vastly different in storyline
+Each storyline is surprisingly deep, offering a unique take on the reasons why people lie, and how even lies with good intentions never prove to be worth it in the end
+Charming characters with witty dialogue 
+8-bit visuals are detailed enough to not grow stale over time
+A unique art style for the character portraits and CGs
+Mini animated cut scenes scattered throughout
+Plenty of CGs
+Excellent soundtrack
+Able to listen to soundtrack, view CGs, and watch the animated cut scenes at your leisure upon beating each game
+Optional collectibles hidden within many of the game's maps

Cons:
-RPG gameplay is far too easy; one can EXP farm a few random enemies and grow over-leveled in a matter of two minutes, making even the final bosses a breeze
-Lots of backtracking. It doesn't take very long, but the sheer amount of it required across all three games adds up

LiEat is a quirky series with a charming cast and compelling mysteries. It's themes about lies are memorable, and the price during steam winter and summer sale is a steal for how much content you get. Furthermore, you can beat the first game in under two hours, so if you buy it and don't like it, you can always refund. But it's more than worth giving it a try!

34300187.review:
LiEat is, over all, a very easy but engaging JRPG. If you view the game as a form of interactive storytelling, you're more likely to enjoy the game, as like I said, it's very easy. The characters' personalities are heartwarming and their stories are intriguing, though. The soundtrack is beautiful and the art is very good. 

My only criticism is that I really desired more animated cinematics and voice acting (there is no voice acting, and very little animated cinematics). Though I understand that it may be challenging to execute, I truly think that those two key features would make the game a huge, popular hit. I would also like to see more in-depth character backstories, arcs, and more installments to really unfold the interesting world of LiEat. It left me wanting more, but it's definitely still worth playing!

Personal rating: 7/10

34284945.review: The story is well written and the gameplay is enjoyable. The game is broken up into three chapters, with each taking around 1-2 hours to complete. I completed the game and earned all achievements in just over 7 hours. This timing is nice because you can sit down for an hour-long session and actually feel like you've acomplished something, unlike most RPG's where an hour is often spent grinding trying to get stronger for the next boss. If you are looking for an epic adventure of heros and villains, with hundreds of hours of gameplay and countless weapon and armor varieties, you'll need to look elsewhere, but if you're feeling like trying a small game with a pretty deep story and strong moral messages with less stress on heavy combat, then give LiEat a try!

34194215.review:
[i]LiEat.[/i] 
Well, how do we start this? It’s pretty much a compilation pack of three short, story-driven RPGs, telling the story of a conman traveling with his trusty loli dragon that eats lies, Efina. 
I won’t say that this game is really good, but it certainly wasn’t even close to mediocre as well.

[h1]The Gameplay[/h1]
There... isn’t really much to write about regarding gameplay. Combat’s there, but it’s pretty basic—attack option, skills (which most of the time is just multi-hitting attacks, but there’s also HP-to-MP conversion, so I’ll give you that), items, and flee; things you’d expect from these kinds of games.

There are also, in fact, things you can find and equipments scattered throughout the game(s) in a non-linear fashion, so you can, for example, cheese your way through fights with that “endgame” weapon you (somehow) found in the first game [spoiler]which is stuck on/in a broken streetlamp... before you can even fight something in the game proper![/spoiler]

[i]I personally consider this a good thing, since it helped me enjoy the story without thinking too much about those pesky encounters. [/i]

There’s also emphasis on puzzles in the third game, but it’s not really that difficult either.
Which brings us to our next topic...

[h1]The Narrative (Story, Characters and Stuff)[/h1]
What LiEat lacks in gameplay, it makes up in the narratives, and it does them well—really well.
Every character (well, at least those who have portraits) are well-rounded and really memorable (arguably even the four maids in the third game, who just serves as a puzzle setpiece!). vgperson are partially to blame for this.

World-building is also there, solid enough for you to understand what’s going on, but also loose enough at some parts to be open to interpretations. 

[i]By the way, there’s also a novelization of the game, also translated by vgperson.  Just throwing this in, since we’re talking about narratives.[/i]

The last but not least...

[h1]The Aesthetics (Music, Artwork)[/h1]
The artwork is somewhat of a middle ground here. It isn’t [i]particularly[/i] distinctive, impressive or anything like that, but there’s a certain charm to it that makes them really interesting.
The same also applies to the music. It’s not good, it’s not bad, but it definitely served its purpose well.

Also, there's animated scenes/CGs! Granted, the animation's just the "one person goes pose one to pose two, end" kind, but still.

[h1]Overall[/h1]
I’d like to re-emphasize that, again, LiEat as a whole is a story-driven RPG, albeit a short one. If you want a strategy-heavy RPG, this isn’t the one for you; but if an interesting setting, characters, etc. is what you’re looking for, this is one of the better choices. 

[i]It also comes with a free soundtrack in the files, so why not?[/i]

34063130.review:
A good game, made of 3 different chapters. You're playing as a humanoid dragon that can make lies manifest, and so the game basically becomes a detectivistic game of sorts with the main mechanic being that you're practically a walking lie detector.

The soundtrack's fairly good and I really liked the characters.

Some of the gameplay mechanics are sometimes frustrating however - sometimes, for example, you'll find a key under a plate, but only AFTER you did something else - even though you've examined the plate before.

Another issue I've had with it is that I feel that the RPG mechanics weren't necessary for the game - it could do without them. And, as it turns out, sometimes you won't get a good ending unless you grind! In a story-concentrated game! I find that unreasonable.

Still, I think that the game's worth the price because of the interesting storyline and characters.

34054930.review: When it comes to RPGMaker games, this is one of the ones that really stands out to me. For gameplay, it isn't exactly revolutionary with 90% of the turn-based RPG moments being fairly easy to complete. However, it especially stands out to me with it's graphics which seem a little different than you're run of the mill RPGMaker game (although still kind of like that but still unique). The art (as in the character pictures and the graphics) are also well drawn. But what really matters for me with these games are the stories. And fortunately, for all of the chapters, the story does not fail to give me a good time (personally, my favorite was the third chapter's story). So yes, buy this. It's cheap and it exceeds the price in it's quality.

LiEat is composed of 3 short stories about the Lie eating dragon and her partner as they go on adventures solving mysteries... Or so I'll like to say.
The game plays more akin to walkable visual novel than an rpg, and even though the menu is designed as if it was truly an rpg, the game is absurdly easy that you wont need to open it 99% of the time.

That said, for a walkable visual novel, I completly recommend it.
The second I started playing I knew that I'll love the characters, and even though the story themes are nothing new (aside from the lie eating) and pretty cliche at times, the game made it enjoyable with such cute characters, making me want to know more about them and how they'll develop in the "mysteries".

So if you like visual novels, or anime style stories, (and a cute loli lie eating character) I recommend it.

Anyways, if you want to support Miwashiba, buy the Steam version; it's cheaper than a pack of smokes.

I have a normal experience with this game - not bad, but not really fun. So for the price of 2,09$ I bought on sale, this is why I gave it a not recommended:

- The art on the game cover is a lie. Many people like it for its "unique", but for me the art is completely "normal", and the "ingame" sprite are horrible.
- RPG-maker standard with nothing good in game play. They have a "money" system that do nothing.
- "3 small games" - 3 parts doesn't connect to each others - means that after farming monster (which contibute nothing to the story) you'll have to do it again when you play another part.
- Too short. Not so much content was added in the game. The map was small and don't have anything really special. I like the idea in part 1, but it was too easy to predict. Part 2 was boring. I feel that they don't really put much work in story making, so this story don't really have depth.

Overall I don't dislike it. As I bought this game for its stories, it didn't have too complex fighting system so I can get my endings soon. But for the price "on sale" of 2,09$ and was never lower than 30%, this is a complete lowball. Please, put more effort into coding and story writing. This game is too expensive.

I would recommend this game if it's less than 1$, or at least the 3 part can connect to each other so no need to farm monster again.

33567960.review:
I've absolutely fallen in love with the characters in this game (Brett is my fav......................). I love how the plot builds up, though there were a couple points where I was confused as to what happened. 

There's three parts to this game in one and you can pick which to play when you first start up the game, and I really enjoyed seeing Efi shown growing up (slowly but surely lmao). There are so many achievements, which were fun as heck to hunt down. I'd recommend using a guide so you don't miss anything. 

The art in this game is great, too. I love the style of the cutscenes along with the sprites/pixel art. The setting design is really pretty, too! I'm not sure if there's any replayability besides for nostalgia's sake or finding achievements missed, but tbh I'd play it again! Each part is pretty short on its own and cute, fun, and not that difficult at all.

33542274.review:
A cute little game with a fantastic idea and world, a great story, but unfortunately only decent storytelling. 
Due to this, it fails to make you feel as much as you maybe could have, and that's too bad. It actually deserved more. 

The gameplay is also kind of standard, almost boring, and not very well balanced I feel, but since the three short stories are so short, it's doesn't wear thin on you, until perhaps you are doing another run for all the achievements afterwards. 

It's a cheap, short enjoyable game that could have been much more. I would like to see this idea, the lie-eating dragon, realized in some other way too. 
It would be awesome in so many medias; a more ambitious game, comic, movie. 
But as it is, it is a cosy little game worthy of it's price.

33385396.review:
[b]LiEat[/b] ist ein relativ lineares RPG Maker Spiel, in dem der Fokus auf der Handlung liegt

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Das Spiel ist in drei Kapitel unterteilt, die sich im Launcher frei auswählen lassen. 
Um die Handlung der Kapitel zu verstehen, ist es nicht unbedingt erforderlich, es ist aber zu empfehlen, sie der Reihe nach zu spielen.

Das Gameplay in LiEat ist relativ spartanisch gehalten. Man läuft herum, interagiert mit den wenigen Personen sowie der Umgebung im Spiel und treibt so die Handlung voran. 

Hin und wieder gibt es einige Pflichtkämpfe, diese sind allerdings bis auf wenige Ausnahmen auch dann schaffbar, wenn man nur das nötigste an Kämpfen mitnimmt. 
Der Großteil der Kämpfe ist optional. Taktischen Tiefgang sucht man hier vergebens und weniger Kämpfe hätten dem Spiel nicht geschadet. Gegner werden in einem Runden-Kampfsystem bekämpft, man bekommt Erfahrung, steigt im Level auf und erlernt neue Techniken. Wie in einem RPG üblich.

[h1]Grafik/Soundtrack[/h1]
Die Pixelgrafik ist schön anzusehen. Die kurzen, aber animierten Zwischensequenzen machen mit ihrem minimalisitschen aber schönen Artstyle einiges her und der Soundtrack ist auch sehr gut.

[h1]Zusammenfassung[/h1]

[b]Pro[/b]
[list]
    [*]Grafisch schön anzusehen
    [*]guter Soundtrack
    [*]kämpfe in der Regel nicht zu lang
[/list]

[b]Contra[/b]
[list]
    [*]Einige Eventflags teils nervig versteckt
[/list]

[h1]Fazit[/h1]
LiEat ist zwar rein vom Genre ein RPG, allerdings liegt der Fokus hier ganz klar nicht auf den Kämpfen. Die Handlung ist nicht filmreif, aber doch ganz nett. Das Spiel ist sehr kurz, aber für den Preis ist es in Ordnung, da vorallem der Artstyle und OST positiv hervorstechen. Wer ein kampflastiges RPG sucht, sucht besser weiter. Wer aber ein kurzweiliges Adventure mit RPG-Elementen, hüpscher Grafik und gutem Soundtrack zu schätzen weiß, kann hier getrost zugreifen.

33288742.review:
This is such a cute and stylistic bite-sized RPG! It has three episodes/chapters bundled into one, which I almost forgot after beating the first part and wondering why it seemed a really short, so don't be like me!

As a turn-based RPG, it's not overly challenging or particularly novel, so anyone looking for something unique on that front should look elsewhere. The little puzzles of trying to find out what are lies and what are truths are quite fitting to the narrative, though sometimes simplistic and, as far as I know, won't directly punish you for blindly guessing. Most of the characters either have charming quirks or are simply endearing, but are fairly predictable unfornately. If you don't mind some tropes, they should be fine though. The shining point of LiEat is the beautiful music and aesthetic that immediately caught my attention when I loaded up the game. For the asking price of $2.99 US, that alone is worth a purchase in my book.

33262599.review: I would highly recommend getting this game. Though the combat itself leaves something to be desired and is pretty repetitive, but the story itself is great to say the least. The story is played out in the 3 games Lieat I/ Lieat II/ Lieat III all of which can be played within roughly an more or less. In the begining you are introduced to the two protagonist: Theodore Leonhart A.K.A.:Leo/hal/theo. Theo is a 23 year old "con"man who likes 3 things: Beer, money, and women. He is a liar who travels from place to place with a mysterious past that is found out later in the game who is accompanied by the other protagonist a small "dragon" that goes by the name Efina or Efi, but she's not the kind of dragon we're used to instead of scales and reptilian she's a small girl that looks roughly 4(though she's 6 months to 1 year at the end). You follow these 2 goof balls as they go through the 3 games helping out in solving crimes the first a murder the second disappearing memories/ a crucifixion and the finale a thief. Each of the characters have unique personalities, but there is a severe lack of characters which is understandable due to the length of each of the games. The combat is earthbound esque you pick up random pieces of gear and level up you don't use money and the game itself is pretty linear and I'd recommend playing it more for the story than the combat. That is all please do buy the game and enjoy :).

32960345.review:
Summary: Efina, a dragon who can eat lies and her con-artist companion Leo venture out different towns and cities solving mysterious and selling secrets to make a living. 

Review: 
9/10 

Steam has a lot of short rpg games but LiEat could easily be the best among them. Im a sucker for anything cute and has a touching story and LiEat has both of those things.

Although LiEat was very story based, there was still a good amount of puzzles and fighting scenes. With games like LiEat, 
a lot of time would be going into venturing around the areas and trying to find secrets, items and unlock achievements. So if you dont like doing that you might not enjoy this game. 

The game has a short range of well developed characters that contribute well to the story. The main chacters are very lovable and make you feel invested into the story. 

The only things that I didnt like was;
- how non-challenging some puzzles were
- how you cant carry items ands levels to the next chapter
- same basic enemies every chapter
- boss fights were extremely easy 

Other than that this game was perfect, adorable and very charming.

32942610.review:
I absolutely love this game, it has an amazing OST, loveable characters, and an intriguing--and occasionally sad--story. I almost didn't get this game; knowing how short it was, but I'm glad I did. I logged a lot more time in this game than actually needed to complete it, but it was all time well-spent. I cannot recommend it enough.

Other notes:
The game comes with all the MP3 files for the soundtrack in its game folder, so you can listen to it whenever.
Of the three story segments, I really loved the story in the first chapter the most, until nearing the end of the third chapter, where that became my new favorite. As that is where the most development is seen for characters and it can seem sad (there are three endings).

32905087.review:
Purchased on Steam Summer Sale Discount. This is an RPGMaker game, so if you dislike those just turn back now.

A sweet little series of stories about Efina, a baby dragon girl who can eat lies... and the con artist she travels with.
The three chapters of the story expand on some details of her caretaker's history, culminating in the third story.

Combat is fairly minimal, and if you uncover the legendary weapons in each chapter you can completely remove all pretense of strategy.
(Exception: the first one has a section where you have to dodge swarms of enemies or face 8+ in combat at once. You can get wrecked pretty fast even with legendary weapons.)

Meeting each of the characters, and seeing their interactions was worth the price.

You'll get maybe 4 hours of overall story and play to reach 100%. Its a pity there's no further story, or games involving Efi, as she would be interesting to watch in the world you've barely set a foot in by the time the last chapter closes.

32873822.review:
Corto pero intenso y con una buena historia. 

Si normalmente no juegas mucho a este tipo juegos rpg y no sabes por donde empezar o quieres probar el género, este es una buena opción para empezar.

+ Pros +

+Combates muy dinámicos, no se hacen pesados.
+Se puede ver un buen desarrollo de personajes a medida que se avanza en la historia.
+Buen repartorio de personajes con todo tipo de personalidades, razas y criaturas magicas.
+El arte en general es muy bonito.
+Buena banda sonora.
+Multiples endings

- Cons -

-Bastante corto (a mi me ha durado unas 5 horas? Más o menos).
-Escenarios escasos o un poco limitados.
-Me hubiera gustado profundizar un poco más en la historia.
-A veces no te dicen lo que debes hacer y puedes perderte un poquito.

⋆ Nota para las personas que NO les gustan los juegos de terror: 

LiEat es un juego un poco/bastante oscuro que tiene toques de horror que se van intensificando a medida que se avanza en la historia, pero es bastante leve y como mucho podrás llevarte un pequeño susto. A veces la música se pone muy tensa o un poco incomoda pero es para dar ambiente.

Nota: 7,5/10 Me ha dejado con ganas de jugar más juegos de este estilo.

32777274.review:
Subito non avevo avuto una buona impressione del gioco in se, ma giocando tutti e tre i capitoli mi sono ricreduto, anche se ci sono diversi elementi negativi che elenco in seguito.

Innanzitutto la storia per ogni capitolo è molto breve, si conclude velocemente eccetto ogni tanto che magari ci si può perdere non capendo cosa bisogna fare di preciso.

In ogni capitolo si recuperano sempre le stesse armi, senza differenza alcuna.

A causa delle mappe molto piccole non è difficile risolvere gli enigmi, basta andare in giro ed interagire con gli oggetti senza seguire una determinata logica per andare avanti nel gioco quando non si sa bene cosa fare.

Per via della storia che è corta, non è necessario salire molto di livello, i nemici sono sempre sempre gli stessi e molto semplici da sconfiggere, anche le battaglie con i boss non richiedono impegno, riuscendo a concluderle in 2 - 3 turni.

A favore la trama che si svolge nella trilogia è molto interessante, cosi come i vari personaggi che si incontreranno nel corso della storia, nel suo piccolo rimane comunque un gioco molto apprezzabile per chi vuole spendere un'oretta senza sapere cosa fare, mi avrebbe fatto piacere se ci fossero state nuove avventure.

32580677.review:
Once again Miwashiba has given us a cute little RPG, with a twist !

Even though the game has three parts (and the amount of time I spent on it) the game is very short. Do not let that fool you into thinking any less of this game. LIEat is one of the underrated RPGs that truly deserves some attention. You have characters that are lovable, a beautifully made soundtrack, and a story that keeps the pace well. Each part has every meaning to the third game, and I personally believe it was well constructed. The game is perfectly priced, and deserves that extra four-eight hours of your time !

LiEat is a very good game, well worth it in my opinion.
Even though it is a simple, short RPG maker game, it makes up for it with the story and the connections you can feel with the characters.
I ended up crying alot throughout the game, probably because I'm very sensitive and I developed a liking to the characters, but mostly because I was crushed when the story didn't continue, I really hope for a part 4.
This game even taught me the affects of lying and how it can destroy people from the inside, so I guess that's pretty good.
Overall, absolutely amazing game, very well made, and affects you on a personal level if you are a sensitive person like myself.
The game also has an absolutely amazing soundtrack, one of the best I have ever heard.

32180758.review:
Un gioco story-driven con una premessa fantasiosa, personaggi assurdi e la grafica del gameboy.

L'impostazione è quella dei classici rpg 16 bit, ma è solo 'apparenza', il fulcro del titolo è far andare avanti la storia parlando con i personaggi e cercando qualche oggetto. Ci sono addirittura combattimenti ma li definirei un 'diversivo', non rappresentano assolutamente una sfida.

I due protagonisti sono: Efina, una bambina che è in realtà un drago (?!) in grado di dare forma alle bugie delle persone e mangiarle... e il tizio un po' losco che si prende cura di lei, uno con parecchie cose da nascondere a cominciare dal nome che cambia continuamente...

E' diviso in 3 episodi (tutti presenti in questa versione) e in ognuno di essi la coppia improbabile si troverà coinvolta in una situazione differente.
Ogni 'puntata' dura poco più di un'ora, presenta un'unica ambientazione di qualche schermata e racconta una storia divertente e interessante.

Difetti per me solo due: le dimensioni ridicole della finestra di gioco (nel senso che è minuscola) e una fase del terzo episodio, una ricerca di oggetti un po' estenuante fatta forse per allungare la durata complessiva abbastanza risicata, per il resto merita se siete amanti delle storie fantasy tipicamente jappo, nonchè delle storie lineari in generale (niente bivi narrativi).

32164855.review: Short, extremely simple, but pretty well polished. Nice art, Nice story, excellent narration.

32157531.review:
Short and sweet is what I would describe this.

LiEat is a story about a small dragon that eats lies and a man that lies. The story is divided into 3 acts, each involving its own mystery.

Its not much of a game. Its incredibly easy, not too challenging, even when there is a little bit of gameplay. Luckily its a story driven experience.

It was a little confusing to tell what I needed to do next, and it required a little of trial and error. You needed to do some things in order so I ended up doing same things over and over until I got it all in order.

The game is short, which I think is a good thing.

I liked the characters. I found all of them to be interesting and fun.

The story was good, but I also wish there was more of it. Its a complex thing, because I think the game has a good length and it ends well, but I also was left feeling that we're not quite done with these characters.

I should also add that the short animations were fantastic, whenever there was animation. I wish there was an anime with that style made out of this, but I somehow doubt that will happen.

Overall, it is an enjoyable game that manages to tell a sweet, endearing story in short amount of time, but the gameplay holds it back. 

If you want a story that's sweet like candy, then I recommend this to you.

很棒的一款轻松冒险的游戏，没有什么太大的难度，只要按照剧情走一般就没什么问题（除了最后的等级限制）。话说一开始找到神器的话基本就无脑过了。。。不过剧情第一位嘛~！
神器位置提示：第一部神器在城镇中间右上角的某个灌木丛处。第二部神器在刚开始进去后俩个猫房间最下方右边的长方形花坛处，挨着摸一摸就找到了。第三部最好找，跟着剧情，上楼后放杂物的房间的某个箱子处，挨着摸总会摸到的。
顺便提示：有的成就中文版没法获得，需要把游戏转成英文版（比如我的那个杀三只老鼠。。。）具体操作：打开你的游戏库→LiEat（右键）→属性→测试→输入“ChineseTest1128”→再选择上方多出来的beta2版本。之后就可以正常获得了。

32081277.review: This game is really cute. It feels like playing a short episodic anime series. The characters are all endearing, and the animations are adorable and very well done. The plot is very simplistic, as are many of the designs and gameplay elements. There are several possible endings, but the game still comes out feeling very linear. If you're a fan of anime, cute things, and lighthearted mystery subplots, I'd give this game a go. It features a simple turn-based combat system much in the same vein as many RPGs in this style of play. The music, art style, and resources all feel unique enough to give the game it's own feel and charm.

I usually don't post reviews, but this game really deserves to be played!

Pros--
+Story-Rich/Story-Based

+Characters have all their own quirks that make them likable
+Very creative ideas in here!
+Soundtrack is very nice and fits well with the scenario it is introduced in

Cons--

For a game merely three dollars, two if you catch it on a sale, it's a real deal you should make! It's story, characters and art are really what make it pop. Even the items fit really well into the world of LiEat!

32039337.review:
Lieat is a very good story. Isn't much of a game. I recomend it.

Short story long, Lieat is a peice by peice story that entales the "Current off the past" Story of a Con man who cares for a young girl. THe what and the why is for you to find out, as this game lives and, dare I say, dies by it's story. This is not a game, it is a story with game elements. A cut ahead of visual novels but a cut behind an RPG horror game. I think it wears its place well.
The game has a nice style. Everything is original to the game, and it's all well done for it's miniscual scale. It has it's own artwork for each character, and even some small animated scenes. The music sets the stage alright enough, and is something I like to listen to casually. 
I'd like to empisise miniscual though. This game is a very small game, easily completed in 2 hours for a first run for a normal player. The game is made even smaller by being cut up into 3 peices, each a labled "game" You'll pick from once you start up the game. Each one is self contained, but they all add up into a complete plot of the main characters. I like how it was handled, too. It gives it a sense of progression within each of the chapters without having to ellate farther down the road. 

Ultimately, this game a bit sized story broken up into bite sized senarios. It's handled well through and through, but do not expect a ton from it.

32032613.review:
Do you have a spare 3 bucks? If so, BUY THIS GAME RIGHT NOW IMMEDIATELY, IT'S WORTH IT.

I gotta say, I was browsing games and I saw this was only 3 bucks and I was like "hm looks cute might as well buy it." Then, I played through LiEat 1 and 2 and I was all... "hooray ship I would've payed like $10 for this IT'S AMAZING?!" It has GORGEOUS graphics and GORGEOUS character designs. It doesn't look like it from the thumbnails, but I fell in love with these characters halfway through because they're SO WELL WRITTEN. Efina and Leo are wonderful, but I personally have an affinity for side characters. Trust me, they're all adorable (subjectively, anyway) and even kind of get their own development? It's pretty funny at points (especially in the achievements and their descriptions) and awfully charming. LiEat also presents an original and intriguing concept with the whole dragon thing and its mythos. It does go a little fast, it took me 2 and a half hours with bathroom breaks, but it's easy enough to do on your own AND the battle mechanics aren't... crucial. I know that may turn some people off from this, but I loved it.

TL;DR if you like pixel games, especially story driven ones, and want to use up the end of your Steam Wallet, LiEat is THE GAME FOR YOU!

31934339.review:
[h1] Game Title: LiEat
Achievement Progress (at the time of post): Completed [/h1]

(My reviews assume you have read about the content of the game in terms of gameplay. I am simply reviewing each individual aspect based on my opinion. This allows for my reviews to be spoiler-free. You may find I rate by different categories in each of my reviews. This is because every type of game is different, and will not have the same content. I think it is pointless to leave a category blank or write 'unrelated', or something similar.)

[h1] Game Content: [/h1] 
[b] Type of Game: [/b] Pixelated RPG, Indie
[b] Graphics and Art Style: [/b] **** - As mentioned above – pixelated, but in anime style. The cutscenes have higher quality graphics, as well. I feel that in this case the pixel graphics are not a hindrance to the game, or a product of lack of developing money, but a way to add a different feel to the game. If the game had Final Fantasy graphics (an example) or something similar, it would not feel nearly as cute and the player would not feel as at home in Effie’s world.
[b] Music: [/b] **** - The music really suits the game, it’s (mostly) fun and upbeat with a different style depending on the chapter or the happenings in the game at that moment. When simply strolling around a new area while ‘Papa’ is off working, the music has a pleasant tune. But when someone has been hurt or disgraced, the music conveys the character’s anger, sadness or malice.
[b] Addictiveness: [/b] *** - Once you start the story, it really makes you question the nature of Effie’s world and how she even came to be. When I was playing it, I thought about it even when I was far from my computer. So I will give it three stars for catching my mind’s attention to the point where I always wanted to play it more.
[b] Storyline and Character Development: [/b] ***** - As mentioned above, the story is breathtaking in complexity and the characters are closely related to their world, which is why I combined those two categories for this review (and also so I don’t have to say ‘as mentioned above’ every five seconds). The characters are complex with intertwining relationships and there are some you might be able to relate to or empathize with in some way. The dragons in this world are often mistreated, with Efina being lucky to have a (somewhat) caring companion, so you can also hear a bit about other dragons’ experiences, although most like to keep it to themselves.
[b] Difficulty: [/b] *** - It’s pretty easy really. The battles are even easier if you find the incredibly overpowered Legendary Gear. Even if you don’t, you shouldn’t have a problem. (P.S – There is already a guide on Steam that shows you how to find all of the gear, so use that as you will!)
 [b] Replay Value: [/b] ** - It’s kinda just one of those games you play again once you have forgotten about it, really. XD
[b] Gameplay and Controls: [/b] *** Standard RPG controls, basically. Nothing special and nothing too difficult.

[h1] Conclusion: [/h1]
[b] Marks Overall (judged by the mode of the numbers): [/b] *** - 6/10 (although I consider it a 10/10!)
[b] Who Should Play This Game?: [/b] Anime RPG lovers, people who appreciate a good story and dragon lovers! XD

[u] Thank you for reading! If you have any suggestions about removing/adding/changing anything in my reviews, please let me know. [/u]

Peace out mein liebes XD

-Kaz D

An incredibly charming trilogy of short RPG's (very few RPG elements though) that tell an interesting story about a mysterious man and the young dragon that travels with him as they travel throughout the land.

The gameplay across all three of the RPG's consists of exploring one locale quite thoroughly as you essentially act as a detective uncovering the truth regarding troubling events at said locale. You'll be collecting items hidden in various containers mixed in with flavor text while learning about a handful of NPC's. The stories in each, while following a similar pattern, are enjoyable experiences and the writing is solid throughout. The main protagonists are an interesting pair and by the end of the games I wanted to go on more journeys with those two.

Also, the price of $2.99 for these games is a steal. The quality to cost ratio there is incredibly high,

31867053.review:
LiEat is a simple RPG-maker game divined into three short stories that follow the lives of a young man and his dragon-girl companion. Each of these episodes centers around a single area where you mainly talk to people, solve puzzels and encounter fights. While these are all essential (and only possible) features of every RPG-Maker game (and usually how well you incorporate each of these determines the game's success), I personally enjoyed a lot how the fighting encounters were incorporated as more of story element rather than forcing them to play a bigger part in game's overrall flow. Granted, this means that the fighting part overrall feels very one-dimensional and easy, which can make the bossfights feel like a letdown.

The stories are mainly detective-like, where you spend most of the time uncovering what has happened. There's a lot of characters, and luckily those that you meet in all three episodes are the most with most substance. Since the game overrall is pretty short (It took me 4 hours to get every single ending & achievement), it does have quite a lot going on and its emphasis on exploring the background of the other MC can feel a bit tedious. On the bright side, most of the dialogue between charachers flows well and the game is sure to leave you warm-hearted after experiencing all of it.

I'd say that the biggest problem I had with the game was the fact that getting a neutral/good ending of the final episode is heavily obscured compared to earlier ones. Nevertheless, its a very warm and fuzzy game with a solid artstyle and writing, and totally worth the few dollars.

31775440.review:
LiEat shows that even with a basic engine like RPGMaker, you can still make some truly interesting and emotional stories.

The story follows a human and a dragon-girl with the ability to eat lies. LiEat has three different arcs, with each one containing a different adventure of the duo. While it may sound too long, LiEat's arcs are bait sized, and can take between half an hour to two hours, and they keep themselves interesting with well made, entertaining characters.

While the stories and gags are great, the battle mechanic is almost non-existant. While both characters do level up and every arc does end with a boss fight, the battle system itself is basic, and can easily be broken by getting the "legendary weapons" hidden at the start of every arc.

although, LiEat can sometimes use the battle system to its merits, having you fight "lies" to progress through investigations and even involves the character's levels into considerations when picking an ending. 

despite all of its flaws, LiEat is short, sweet, and interesting, and is recommended for everyone who can see past its visuals.

31627521.review:
This game, Wow. At first, I didn't have high hopes for it. I bought it one day, Then left it sitting in my library for about a week. I decided to finally play it when I had nothing to do for around 30 minutes while I waited for my game to update. I ended up playing the whole story 4 hours straight, and I did not regret it.

The story was lovely. I loved the dialogue, and the personality of the characters. Especially Elfi. Her dialogue was adorable, how she was really clueless about many things. The art was really good as well. It isn't as sparkly, and shiny as the art of really good artists, but it gives off a really nice charm.

I wasn't expecting cutscenes from this game. Though really short, I feel that it gave a really big impact to the story. Text, and pictures can't always tell a story better than it being animated.
Though saying that, The cutscenes are just around four seconds, but it was still a nice addition overall.

The first two games are pretty much the same thing, but the third game really starts getting into the characters. That's all I can say about the three without spoiling it to much. Though I'm not saying the first two are repetetive. They both have a unique story. The second one teared me up. Don't even ask me about the third.

For the mechanics, The battle system is pretty simple, and most monster fights are pretty easy. The bosses have really high health, but they don't hit as hard if you do the right thing. Though the main part of this game is solving problems, I wouldn't necessarily say it's a puzzle game. I don't know the word, or how to explain it, but it's like piecing the parts together to get the answer. I guess it's like that.



OVERALL:
The game has a lovely story, and the puzzle part of the game isn't to hard, but it can be a challenge here, and there. Overall a wonderful experience, at least for me. I recommend it for anyone who's in for a good story.

31331226.review:
Sweet little lies

LiEat is a short jrpg with simple combat based on the unique premise that you can see lies and eat them.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=897291422

Gameplay
Hindered by acutely hidden event flags. The game refuses to progress until you talk to the correct NPCs in the correct order and examine the right items at the right time. What a nuisance. 

Visual
The game runs at a low resolution with sprite work that isn't partiuclarly noteworthy. There are brief videos sprinkled throughout that emphasize cuteness. 

Sound
Only a handful of songs, many of which will grate on your nerves after about the fifth loop. 

Plot
Very creative premise but entirely too short to invest the player. The game is split into 3 separate, unrelated chapters. With each one lasting an hour and only a handful of characters, you'll likely see most of the plot twists coming.

Spectacle
Other than a dozen cute animations and an adorable protagonist, there isn't much noteworthy about this game.

Difficulty
Without a guide you'll be running laps around the map wondering what item you need to click on to just progress the game. Other than that, you have to go out of your way to die. You can save at any time. 

Two and a half out of five stars
Decidedly average. I'd prefer if event-flag triggering items would sparkle to signal that the player needs to examine them.
