25242464.review:
[h1]Short Review[/h1]

6/10.  If you like short RPG games with anime style storylines, LiEat might just fill that need for you.   It’s light gaming with interesting characters, clues to uncover, and lots of text. Oh, and little pixely people.


[h1]PROS[/h1]
-	A nice blend of pixel art with hand drawn anime cut scenes
-	puzzles are not very difficult
-	a good background fantasy world with a strong character driven dialogue story
-	leveling up and upgrades easy to achieve
-	a good soundtrack

[h1]CONS[/h1]
-	game towns and rooms look very similar
-	some doors, messages, and openings are not apparent
-	first chapter is somewhat slower than second and third.
-	RPG elements are barely there


[h1]Long Review[/h1]

A close family member recommended this game to me as an easy game to relax with. I don’t really play any RPG Maker games, so it was a gamble whether I would like this or not.  LiEat started a little slow and didn’t have a ton of RPG action going on, but it actually makes up for it with charm and characters.


[h1]First Impressions[/h1]

Firing up the game, you start with a bit of back-story for the first chapter.  It begins with an explanation of the relationship of some vampires, wolves, and a village.  I won’t add more than so that I don’t spoil the story.  After watching the opening, I was a little confused because it seemed like this was a vampire game of sorts.  Shortly afterwards, the two main characters Efi and her Papa - who says, “remember, call me Leo here” - are introduced. 

Those two characters are the beginning of the real story – Efi and Leo.  It’s about those two, not the vampires – at least not for a good while.  Their dialogue is charming and personal.  Efi is a little girl, not a teenager so her affections and emotions come off as pure and innocent. She only helps Leo with heartfelt devotion, not from any hidden motives.  Leo, on the other hand, changes his name in each town we enter.  We’re never quite sure what he is up to and what his motives are.  Efi even calls him Papa more than by his name since he doesn’t make his background clear to her.  His personality is murky and he feeds Efi a healthy amount of lies – which becomes interesting later on.  It’s this dynamic relationship that fuels the story.  They both have a history together that makes the dialogue feel like we’re eavesdropping on them.  Each short conversation is filled with quips and witty remarks.  My only problem is that sometimes the banter starts out well but can suddenly become too silent.  Conversations will be be moving along only to be shortened to “…!” or  “… … ”.  I understand pauses in dialogue, but it seemed like there were a great deal of them over and over.  Thankfully, this improved a bit towards the middle of the chapter as the story fleshed itself out and greatly improved from chapter two on down.  


[h1]Gameplay & Story[/h1]


 So, what do Efi and Leo do in this game exactly?  They are pretty much detective investigators.  Efi is a Dragon – a being created by someone’s wishes.  She is somewhat immortal and possesses a special power unique to herself - she eats lies.   Efi and Leo - a.ka. Hal or Theo - spend the entire game solving detective cases.  This makes LiEat more of a mystery adventure game than an RPG.  Yes, you will use RPG elements and fight monsters, but that part of the game is actually very minor.  The combat is simple with attacks, skills, and powers.  You’ll walk and open doors, drawers, etc and find some items to level up.  It’s very accessible to people who have not played RPG maker games, so no worries about dying throughout.  However, the bulk of the game is solving a dectective who-done-it case and saving the day.  Each chapter is a new adventure for Efi and her Papa.

Upon playing a chapter you encounter an x-factor that surprised me. These “Dragons” , a whole race of non-humans, are mostly employed in a police force of sorts and help in each investigation.  Usually, they help on a side quest while leaving the bulk of the game to Efi and Papa, but it does add some great opportunities for character development and side missions.  There are some touching scenes with Efi, who seems at odds with being who she is.

If you like anime style dialogue, you can very easily imagine voice actors voicing this script and it’s actually done nicely.  There are some translation issues here and there, but its nominal.   The entire story is dialogue driven with the exception of the short intros at the beginning of each chapter.

[h1]Graphics & Sound[/h1]

RPG Maker graphics.  You’ll have limitations in details and color palette. It’s done as well as it can be within those constraints.  You will see both still-shot cut-scenes and fully animated cut-scenes for important scenes during gameplay.  There is a color tone of magenta and muted green with soft tones of pastel orange, red, purple, green, and mauve.   This is very nice to look at, but there are limits of the RPG maker engine itself.  Sometimes, I’d have no idea there were scrawled words on a wall or a door to the side.  

The soundtrack has a hint of Harry Potter in it’s tonality  - a whimsical magical composition.  Generally, nothing unnerving or irritating since it loops for most of the levels.  Additionally, none of the sounds effects were annoying or overdone.

	
[h1] Final Thoughts [/h1]

If you like dialogue driven anime, adventure games, or episodic RPG’s then you might enjoy this game.  The actual RPG elements are very light, however, and anyone seeking a moderate RPG experience may want to look elsewhere.  LiEat is about solving mysteries and characters, less so about leveling up or exploring.  You may or may not fall in love with the main characters, but one thing that stands true in each chapter is the emotion of the story.  It takes a few chapters, but there was a surprising depth to the storytelling that I was not expecting later into the game.  After the first chapter I was only mildly interested, but by the second chapter I was involved in learning more about the characters.  By the third chapter I was engrossed in seeing what happened towards the end.  

Speaking of the ending, there are a few of them depending on how you play out your choices.  Save your game at least one extra time after you get past the stairwell if you want to see them all.
	
I was pleasantly surprised how much I enjoyed playing this game. It’s only $3 and frankly priced just right for the amount of content you’ll get.  While not a must play game, it’s exactly what I was a told to expect – a relaxing little  RPG mystery.

Regardless this was an enjoyable experience and I hope you will enjoy LiEat as much as I have. You should also check out Miwashiba's other games too such as Alice Mare and 1bitHeart.

I may sound like I'm overexaggerating as it is my own opinion but the game is pretty cheap so give it a try.

25233741.review:
I feel like most reviews don't actually focus on balancing this game's ups and downs properly, both the positive and the negative ones. The positive ones overvalue what people perceive as "cute" while the negative ones bash the game too much. There are a few reviews that make a justified description or review of the game. Obviously I'm not doing any side a favor with this. I'll explain why I can't recommend this game after stating a few facts about it. Keep in mind I'll be taking in consideration the price of the game and what the game offers for that value.

[h1]The TLDR pros/cons version:[/h1]

[b]PROS[/b]
- Cutscenes and Artworks for some in game events.
- Movement is fluid.
- The overall style is cute.
- Small optional interactions you can do in the game to make yourself feel more involved with the story (such as poking Leo when he sleeps because why not).
- Multiple endings.

[b]CONS[/b]
- Lack of consequence if you do certain mistakes;
- The lack of actual places to explore per chapter makes the game feel repetitive and boring on the long run.
- No combat depth despite being advertised as a JRPG. Additionally, if you grind some levels you can actually become immune to damage, including boss damage.
- Despite being advertised as "A fantastic JRPG focused on storytelling." the storyline is very short and doesn't hold up to that statement. The story is appropriate for the price of the game. Don't get your hopes up.
- Some in-game designs for characters are poorly made (especially the artwork of characters on the right of the dialogue).
- The in-game money you acquire is useless.

For those interested [u]in more details[/u], I'll start off with the [b]pros[/b]:

1. I didn't expect any type of cutscenes at all. I thought it's just some trailer animation. It was a nice surprise. It makes it easier to imagine what's depicted or how the characters actually look in an RPG viewed from the top.
2. For this price I had some feelings that movement speed or the FPS cap would be an issue. Good thing I was wrong. The movement is fluid and fast enough for the size of each map.
3. While it doesn't captivate me as much as others, the style is chibi-oriented and cute.
4. The small and sometimes meaningless optional interactions you can do does make it, at least for me, a better way of appreciating the game, rather than not having them at all.
5. It's great to have multiple endings to slightly personalize the story depending on some actions you do. Some might argue that a linear great ending would be better rather than branching out.

Now for the [b]cons[/b]:

1. The moment I saw Lies that you can battle I immediately thought of "hey, this looks like a nice detective game! Maybe if I pick the wrong choice, it's gonna affect the case or make me redo it...or at least lose a certain amount of HP". Sadly it doesn't expand on it and there's no consequence with failing to find the lie(s) (unless you count the fact that you waste some time on some battles)
2. Being used to JRPGs, I expected more zones than what it has. There really isn't too much to explore. But for the game's price I can't really complain that much.
3. If a game has "JRPG" or even "RPG" as its genre, I expect some combat depth and some grinding. Sadly the only part where I had to "think" was in the first chapter where I used an AoE attack to get rid of a line of mobs. Overall, you can just keep mashing the Attack option and still win. And if you reach a certain level with your characters you become immune to damage.
4. The storyline is okay for the price attached. I really wish there were more scenes and more character development because I wanted to get to know some characters more than the game allows me to. I spent some time in RPG Maker. Adding text is not that hard (And yes, I do imply this game was made in RPG Maker or something similar). But like I said before, for the price I paid, it's not a big issue.
5. There's a lot of pixelation done with the characters in the artwork shown on the right of the dialogue, such as Leo looking way too low quality compared to others and not too appealing to the eye. Maybe that's just me, I don't know.

Why do I not recommend this game? Because it could have been something awesome like "To the Moon" or "Ib" with enough hardwork and patience. I would buy the game at a 5-10 euro price tag if the game was focused on the following:
- More places to explore
- More optional dialogue and interactions with the characters
- Expand the combat by adding some strategy to it
- Most importantly: Make it a detective JRPG game where I interrogate people and find the truth about the case.
This game had the potential to be a JRPG focused on finding the culprit and solving mysteries. Not to the lengths of "Danganronpa" or "Ace Attorney" series, but at least give more player input and consequences related to uncovering who done what they did. It has a dragon loli who can detect lies, for crying out loud!
I'm not gonna go into details on how this could be made as everybody has their own ideas of how to improve the game. However, I really wanted some negative effects if I'm doing something wrong with finding lies, make me find who the culprit it according to clues and then give me the option to accuse someone. Heck, maybe use in-game money you acquire to buy hints.


[h1]Conclusion:[/h1]
The artwork is okay, the BGM is okay, the story is okay, overall this game is average. And that's the problem. I really wanted to recommend this game but I can't. And it's not because of the value of the game, it is for what is worth. It's because it could have been something awesome and unforgettable giving the right time, patience, hardwork, and price. Yes, I'm not recommending this game only because it wasn't polished to its fullest potential. I wanted this game to be awesome (with an appropriate price for its greatness), but the dev team decided to stop and deliver an okay game for its current price.
 
I am aware that the reason for not recommending it isn't truly justifiable. From an objective standpoint I'd recommend this game. But this is a review with my own personal opinion. Thus, a subjective point of view is more appropriate.

A message to all reviewers who keep saying stuff like "omg that girl is so cute and you should buy the game because of that!": You are overvaluing the "cute" aspect of the game way too much. Is it really that big of a thing for a dragon loli that discovers life to be this game's selling point? Or the artstyle? Because I don't think so. Maybe that's just me. Who knows.

A message to all reviewers who say this game is "horrible" or bash certain aspects of the game in an exaggerated manner: don't forget you spent 2 to 3 euros/dollars on it. For that value, don't expect too much out of it. It's not gonna be Final Fantasy. As mentioned above, the game is neither good or bad. It's average. If you're that disappointed, just sell the Trading Cards you get from it and compensate some of the money you spent. If you're lucky enough to get a Foil type of Trading Card, you can sell that for at least the amount of money you spent on the game.

25219775.review:
I don't want to hype this game (because hype ruins everything), but for the record, LiEat will always have a special place in my heart.

What you get when you purchase this game is actually three games. Or you might say the game consists of three episodes. Each episode has its own self-contained plot, and there are a few questions or over-arching plot threads that persist across each episode, so it's not *entirely* episodic. The combat takes a backseat to storytelling. It's simple turn-based, and not really difficult. But it really doesn't add anything to the game or take it away. It's just kind of there.

The stories, even if you find them predictable, you will find well-executed. The game just throws you straight in, and uses a great combination of character interactions and the events in each episode to give the player information on who Leo and Efi are and how their world works without bogging down the experience with tedious heaps of information. These games reward exploration. Even if you are not required to speak to a character again, often visiting them again after the story has progressed a little will reward you with new and interesting dialogue. I personally enjoyed all the characters, Efi especially :P

The art is adorable and the music really brings the atmosphere together. There is a good balance of humor, and seriousness in this game. This game's only crime is being too short. It's only $3 and imo it's worth more than that. Buy this game. It's good.

25207265.review:
There isn't an RPG I know of that has held such charm and innocence above it's rather darkly surreal world like LiEat. You play as Theobald Leonhearts and his dainty companion Efina through 3 games, each taking place after one another. You follow them through 3 different settings each one sprinkling you bite-sized bits of Theo's and Efi's personality and past while foreshading a deeper meaning to your adventures. Each game plays the same way only differing in story and setting so the game will be evaluated in a general sense.

Soundtrack
The sound design in the game works well but isn't anything special at all. It gets moody or bright when it needs to be. Overall the music seems to give off the feeling of bittersweetness which is fitting for the game.

Gameplay
The gameplay here is what you expect of an RPG with a little twist where you can decide if you indeed want to engage or not in combat beased on being given an option to decided whether or not a lie is genuine or not. This makes the combat pretty much optional save for the bosses and the few unavoidable fights. However the ending you recieve can be determined by your character level but unfortunetly the enemy scaling is really bad. All the enemies save for boss characters are lies in a physical creature-like form and it is possible to get strong enough to destroy the bosses by grinding on the weakest enemies. 
They just give you way to much exp and this becomes more apparent each game the first being the most balanced in my opinon. I also find it odd you get money too but never use it for anything. The game progresses for the most part by speaking with characters or checking objects in a sequential matter which is sometimes boring to be honest. Sometimes this leads you to pressing 'Z' on everything you come in contact with or searching around far too long. This also led to me finding the legendary weapons in both the 2nd and 3rd games which was pretty cool because they were hidden invisibly but they really break the game and I don't recommend even picking them up unless you just want to enjoy the story. In the second game you can find the legendary weapon on the second screen right at the beginning which is very unfortunate but the thrid game fixes this. 
Overall the gameplay is fine if a little imbalanced and sometimes mundane. It seems comfortable not taking the idea of deciding which lies are genuine further than a plot device rather than a real  fight mechanic. I liked that Efi follows you like Pikachu would in the old Pokemon games but was dissapointed that I couldn't turn around to converse with her.

Story
The story is the meat of this game in my opinion but it sure takes it's time selling you on it and I really felt like most of it was in the 3rd game while the other 2 were just primers for the big drop. It's not the best but not the worst and once I was learning more about Theo and Efi I definetly wanted more and the game delivers well on that part. This game contains interesting lore where dragons are born with human appearences and each with a special ability and it delves a bit into the idea but often I found that the abilities were pretty lame. For the most part the characters you engage with are interesting and have a personality that is acceptable but they are mostly forgettable. Sometimes the dialog makes no sense given the context an example of this is the responses you get from the maids after completing the investigation on them in the 3rd game. The most enjoyable moments here are the interactions between Efi and Theo.

LiEat is an RPG mostly centered around it's story and the relationship between the two main characters. The combat is almost optional and could use some work to balance out. The settings could be better since the 2nd and 3rd game's are too similar. It is thematicly cute feeling but keeps a dark and surreal tone when it comes to the plot devices which was pretty neat. Overall it is enjoyable but rough around the edges at times. You can tell if this game is going to be enjoyable for you almost immediatly. I say follow your gut on whether or not you want to play this one because it is an experience that is varied but what is appealing about it very apparent and doesn't stray far from that.
  
Graphics
The art design is what you would expect from an RPG Maker game however LiEat sets itself apart from the others with it's brief animations which are usually used to introduce a character for the first time or during key events. The static images that are sometimes used instead of an animation in these sequences are okay, they usually feature a character posing cooly. My only gripe here is the character portraits that appear when one of them is talking. They are cool looking but are harsh on the eyes to make out the smaller details in them. 

For me this was a 6/10 slightly above average but could have been a 7 if the game had a little more strategy involved in the combat it was just too much of a breeze. I enjoyed it in parts but didn't in others but I'd still recommend becasue the price is very fair for what it offers.

25195934.review:
LiEat is a story-based game comprised of three somewhat short stories. There are some RPG gameplay elements to it, but I would say the main focus would be the stories.

The characters within the game are interesting and have their own unique traits. The stories connect to each other and build upon the game's world, which I appreciate. 25194068.review:
Here we have an odd one but a very good odd one. For starters, the game looks like an RPG but it could practically be a visual novel. It has the entire RPG coat of paint with stats and equipment and such but none of it really matters since there's almost no fighting. You actually aquire equipment faster than you can use it and collect more restorative items in one playthrough than you would need for 10 playthroughs. In other words, it's all about detectiving and the story.

You play a conman/detective who is a habitual liar and also as a young dragon who looks about 5 or 6 but is actually just a year old. Said dragon eats lies but she can't eat Mr. Conman's lies since the person has to admit the lie and she has to know it's actually a lie before she can eat them. So this game has 3 chapters and with each new chapter the duo move to a different town where Mr. Conman dons a new identity and they have a new mystery to solve. It's all well-written and interesting.

There are some flaws, though.

First, in Chapter 1, there was a point where you had to identify lies and clues were hidden in the area to help with that. I thought that was cool but it turns out that sort of mechanic was not really used after that. It would have been nice to have that mechanics used a lot more and in more clever ways. A lot of the time you're just guessing, the answer was spoon-fed to you or it's a "clean up the lies" segment where everything is a lie and you don't have to worry about getting it right. 

Second, TINY TINY window. If there's a way to run this game fullscreen, I never found it. Not even Alt+Enter works. The game normally runs in a 640x480 window.

Other than that, I would highly recommend the game. All three chapters can be done in 6 hours or less but for $3, that's still a good deal.

LiEat reminds me of those classic RPG style game. Turn based battle, hidden treasures, attention to details and very well written story with well designed characters. The story is very interesting and you always want to know more.

PROS:
- Many unique characters
- Great soundtracks
- Different possible endings
- Great story and good storytelling

CONS:
- Game is only a couple hours long (took me 5 hours to unlock all achievements)
- You cannot purchase anything even though you can earn Gold from battle. This leaves a sense of "incompleteness" in the game.
- The game is not difficult at all (very straight forward battle system)

Basically LiEat is a short and sweet game with all your favorite RPG elements in it. The game focuses on storytelling more than anything.

A short, charming RPG.

It's definitely not all that challanging, you have to make an effort to lose for some acheivements and the puzzles are very simple, so it's a pretty laid back play. Some things could probably be a tad more coplex (You could see through the plot pretty easily so there were no surprises there at all), but it's not really meant to be that at the same time.

The overall aestetic has a lot of charm to it: Good Soundtrack, likeable characters and an interesting world (the little that you see of it), and the animations that they use accationally are quite nice. 

Pretty much the only thing I didn't like was how specific some of the puzzels where, such that you could go around and check all the objects and find nothing, but after you tal to a specific person then it's suddenly 5ft from where you are standing...but that's just me.

Definitely worth the buy for the price. Would definitely recomend for someone who likes RPGs, but is looking for a shorter, more relaxed play.

24874517.review:
The LiEat trilogy is a very short but sweet tale of Efina the Lie-Eating Dragon and her guardian, whose name and face change with each passing town.  Together, they work to... make money!  Naturally, though, in a world with dragons, that's hardly ever all they do.

Oftentimes, people's lies start to grow as they continue to tell them.  Ultimately, a person can become so lost in their lies that the lies take physical form, taking over the person in question and turning them into a monster.  Whether by fate or dumb luck, our heroes almost always end up having to solve these lies and uncover the truths of the people they meet.  However, even as they defeat the lies of others, the lies of a certain guardian start to grow all too apparent...

All in all, this is a really cute and enjoyable story.  It's very short, with each game taking roughly an hour to complete.  However, it's a very charming little game with a lovable cast and a beautiful ending.  ...Well, actually, there are multiple endings, most of which only appear if you fail.  But the good ending is beautiful!  If you're ever in need of a fun distraction, LiEat is definitely the game for you!

LiEat war bei mir eines dieser Spiele, die ich mir im Summer Sale gekauft habe und nach einer Stunde bereits wieder vergessen hatte. Wochen später entdeckte ich den Namen in der Liste meiner Spiele mit der Reaktion "Was zur Hölle ist das denn?". Da ich nichts besseres zu tun hatte, entschied ich mich, es mal auszuprobieren... 2 Stunden später hatte ich das erste Kapitel durch und hörte nur ungern aufgrund Zeitmangels auf. Inzwischen habe ich alle 3 Kapitel sowie alle Achievements des Spiels durch (bisher erstes und einziges Spiel auf 100%). 

Dieses Spiel bietet eine wundervolle Story inklusive interessanter Haupt- und Nebencharaktere und einer guten Portion Humor, sowie Secrets und verschiedener Endings. Ein anspruchsvolles Kampfsystem sucht man zwar vergebens, aber wen das nicht stört, für den gebe ich eine klare Kaufempfehlung.

Zu erwähnen wäre hier noch der wirklich gute Soundtrack, den es kostenlos (!) dazu gibt.

Alles in allem war dieses Spiel eine wahnsinnig positive Überraschung für mich und ich habe jeden Moment ingame genossen.

24753546.review:
LiEat is a short and sweet JRPG. The pixel sprites are beautiful and the illustrations and short animated scenes are simple, yet pretty. The soundtrack is also very pleasant, with my favourite tracks being the music box-style ones that play during boss battles. The story is rather straightforward and all characters are captivating. Efi's relationship with her [strike]tsundere[/strike] "papa" is funny and heartwarming.

The only downside I can think of is that the battles are [i]way[/i] too easy. If you check the global achievement stats, you'll see the least common achievements are the Bad End ones, which require you to lose to each chapter's final boss. This is especially frustrating in the last chapter. You'd expect battles there to be crazy difficult (they give you SO MANY HEALING ITEMS too), but they're actually the easiest in the whole game (boss battle included). 
Considering how short the game is, you may also find it a little pricey depending on your region and currency.

Despite those 2 downsides, however, I still heavily recommend this. Easy battles aside, the characters are charming, the art is lovely and music is beautiful. 8/10

24580456.review:
This a heartwarming / heartbreaking story about a travelling con-man who goes by many names, and Efi, a dragon who can see and eat lies. The premise really is quite unique and the story fully makes use of it. There are also subtle symbolisms if you take the time to notice them. All 3 games in LiEat are about an hour long each, and each involve solving some kind of mystery. They mostly play like an adventure game with multiple endings where the two play detective and hunt for clues and pick out lies.

The translation is pretty spot-on, but some subtleties are always lost. For example, the con-man calls Efi 'runt', which might be a tad rougher than the more endearing 'chibi' in the original. Other than the illustrations by Ike which either have striking perspectives or are absolutely adorable, Miwashiba did everything else himself - writing, music etc. and it's great!

The conclusion is quite awesome in tying up all the loose ends. Such is its finality, that Miwashiba said in the afterword in the novelized prequel that there cannot be a fourth game, otherwise everyone's characterizations would break. However, for the 3 games we did get, give it a shot and you won't be disappointed.

24111227.review:
I havent finished the game yet but from what I've finished; I've really enjoyed the game so far.

While the game itself is short, each part of the story is split into 3 chapters / games.
For everyone who likes story-driven RPG games, I'd suggest this to you! 
However, the game is very weak on the fighting system. You don't need to grind as much as you might expect from the usual JRPGs. Which is fine, but it still needs a bit of extra work in my opinion. There is no variety of monsters aside of the bosses, I wish there were more disgungished differences between the lie monsters but theres barely any in-battle. (Outside of battle they have different looks yes, but in-battle, there isn't much difference. They all have the same attack moves so there's nothing special to it?)

Aside of that: visuals. The visuals in this game are good! As a fan of anime art-style, I felt the art style used here really fit the characters. The pixel art as well is very lovely and I do fancy it quite a bunch. At start the weird filter of the game's first chapter bothered me, but as I proceeded the story; I began to understand it was part of the atmosphere each chapter gives you. 

The music is fantastic, very soothing and very nice to listen to. It's very fitting to the atmosphere the visuals & story is trying to give you. 

The characters are fantastic as well, there is literally no other complaint other than I wish I knew more about them! Theo does his job great playing the "mysterious" character, and Elfie is way too adorable! Honestly in every JRPG I tend to hate one specific character because of traits that I don't like, but I don't really think theres any character to hate here. All of the characters you get introduced to are reasonable and have well thought-out backgrounds. Some remain more mysterious than the other, which is fine as it leaves things better to interpretation to how they may be like outside of our protagonist's views! Each story is left with an "open-ending" to what happens next to these characters aside of the protagonists and I like that.

Honestly, my only complaint about this game is: I wish it was longer! I wish the plots were longer as well, or that one chapter had more to it than the main plot and the tiny errands you do! Because the plots are so short, the maps are short as well. There is barely anything to explore. However if you're bored, inbetween you might come to find some interesting things. (I stole money from the snake lady just by checking out one of her bookshelves haha!)

24020402.review:
There are a lot of things that I have problems with when it comes to games. One of the biggest ones is 'overstaying your welcome'. See, I don't handle horrendously long games that well. Well... that might not be true. It's probably better to say that developers don't often make a long game a good one. I think this is driven by an industry standard in which long games = better games? Or perhaps you can charge more for a longer game, people might like to pay for a certain number of hours of playtime. But quite frankly, I think that's a horrible justification for long games. That's essentially saying that you made a game long to make the game long. It's like padding on a woman, sure, it might make them seem more appealing. But at the end of the day you're both disappointed. Ironically for the reason behind this game! Lying.

The game's title is a very clever combination of the words 'lie' and 'eat'. You will at some point in the game eat lies. Simple enough, right? Right. You play... well I don't want to spoil the plot for this one so let's just call them Dude and Efi. Efi is the dragon, she can eat lies. Dude is an information broker, but he seems to play detective. That's where the lie-eating dragon comes in. You, the player, deduce what the lies are, and then eat them. You arrive at the scene. Something has gone down. You talk to everyone, gather clues, and then when you're ready to do your deduction game, you're given a few 'lies'. Of the lies, there will be truths hidden. What this means is that you'll have to use your notes and what the lies are saying to deduce which are actual lies and which are truths. You don't want to eat the truth (apparently it tastes bad).

Combat is turn-based like every JRPG and their mum. But that's not so bad because the combat doesn't make up the bulk of the game. Combat is a fine method of progressing through a game, but it cannot carry a game. That's where the rest of the game's elements come together. LiEat has a magnificent aesthetic. It reminds me of Pokemon Gold and Silver era. It's also kind of amusing when you realize how the art links together, but that's probably just my gaming quirk. For instance, there's a room with a giant eye in it. Really, it's just two layers. A hole, and a background with an iris looking drawing on it. As you move through the room, the iris background moves with you, making it appear as though the eye is following you for creepy effect! Is that impressive? Not really. But it's my blog and I'm going to squee over it because I think it's awesome. The art style just really comes together. It has this Victorian feel to it... if I'm using that adjective properly.

The music is fabulous! The music really sells the theme. It's classy, it's silly, it's spoopy, it's whatever the tone needs it to be. And it's amazing how I never noticed the transitions until I noticed the transitions. That's not the way I meant to word that. What's a better way to say this? I never noticed the transitions until it was apparent that the mood in the story had changed to fit it? Maybe the best way to say this is that I never noticed transitions. The music always fit the tone and you, the listener, could not distinguish when the tone changed because it's just done that well.

The story is generally rather basic. You could likely tell how things were going to play out well in advance. And perhaps that's the game's intention. Each game (LiEat 1, LiEat 2, LiEat 3) started with some kind of storybook sequence. A myth, a dream, something like that. And you could tell how the dream applied when you started playing the game and talked to all of the characters to get a feel for the scenario that you were about to play. The dialogue is well-written, each of the characters are as interesting as they need to be for their involvement in the plot. 

Of the three games, I think the second one was the one best made. The first one felt like the stretching of legs, to see if this game concept would work. The characters are so adorable how could this game concept not work? The deduction game in the first one is rather simple. I got the bad ending first because curious =(

The second game was where the writers really seemed to hit their stride. The setup was great, the characters were rather flaunty, and the deduction game (while still simple) felt more involved. It felt like more work had gone into it somehow. I don't know if that's true, but it's how I felt. And Efi just seemed to be on her game for funsies the most in this one.

I don't think the third game had a deduction game, and this might be why I rate it second. I tend to favor the third game more because it ties together the threads of the first two games, but it didn't have a deduction game and the method to getting the good vs bad ending seems a bit too simple, which I'll spoil because it's that bad. To get the good ending you need to be a certain level before fighting the final boss. That's it. That's not what I want for my story endings! I want some choice that I made earlier in the game to be more significant! But the story itself reveals so much about the characters in the game. And I was more invested in the characters in these games anyway. So I rate three below two for gameplay, but three above two for story. 

The thing that wraps this up in a nice little bow is that it's wrapped in a nice little bow. The game is as long as it needs to be. This is the way I like my games. Show up, get in, get out. It didn't drag itself out for the sake of runtime. It didn't drag itself out enough to make me lose interest in the characters. It had three short stories that it wanted to tell. It told these three short stories in a timely manner. And for that I applaud it. It's self-contained, a lesson that I think more developers should take to heart. 

At the end of the day, I highly recommend this game. At the time of writing it's $2.39 on Steam. That's like $0.80 per short story. It's worth it, I promise you.

23945078.review:
LiEat is an underpriced gem. It's really three small games in one, tied together by common characters and a few other details. Each game takes maybe an hour and a half at most to play, so it's certainly short. It has some RPG mechanics, but the combat is (possibly intentionally) fairly one-dimensional. Doors have functional but interesting, or more specifically large, hitboxes. Despite sounding those all sounding like bad characteristics, none of these detracted from what LiEat seemed to be doing and none of them bothered my enjoyment of it.

What LiEat brings to the table, and what caught my attention through all three parts, is a game full of charm. The mechanical and plot choices help present itself this way, making for a game that coheres with its stylistic choices. I never felt like the game was too wordy, yet I found myself repeatedly amused by item descriptions, invested in every character with a portrait I met, and sincerely trying to guess what the next piece of the story would be. The music was pleasant and atomospheric as needed. The game has a built in difficulty setting, if for some reason you want the combat to feel a little more on edge, that felt more organic than most games, where easy/normal/hard is often just thrown in settings somewhere.

All in all, if you're looking for a cute story, some well built characters, and nice music, this is a game worth playing. At a mere three bux, this game earns its price easily.

23908800.review:
This game is short, cute, and heavy on the feels in some places. Simply put, it is a good game. 
For some people, the length may bother them. It can be finished in about 2-3 hours, if you do not go achievement hunting. The pixil sprite design works well, like something made with RPG Maker or that came out on the Gameboy or NES ages ago. The story, about a newly hatched dragon that eats lies, is augmented with occassional still images and mini-cutscenes to help further the plot and immersion. The Achievements are also somewhat interactive, a few corresponding to gameplay choices that benefit you, or make you look like a jerk.
LiEat is divided into three parts; LiEat I, II, and III. All come with this purchase. Each story builds on the character interaction between the heroine and her caring yet curmudgeonly "papa." The other two reoccuring characters that help progress the story and develop the characters are a pair of policemen. And hidden around the game are hints to the final confrontation that occurs in part III. 
Besides the short length, one other downside is that the worlds in each part are small, and you will rarely if ever need to go beyond Level 10 for each boss. 
Saying any more and I fear I'll start stepping into Spoiler territory, so I'll stop here. Suffice to say, this is a short game but very good and worth the price. if I had to score, I'd give it an overall 8/10.

23838229.review:
My first actual review, all reviews i have done was some art of trolling to recieve funny votes(didnt recieve any lol).

[b]TL;DR[/b] Awesome game, Awesome story, Unique plot, heartwarming Characters, Short story but awesome gameplay; Aka must buy!

          First of all, im mostly an online gamer. I dont spend any time on offline games, except rare cases such as undertale, to the moon, A Beginners guide and such. Personally i enjoy single player games that are focused on the story. And this was one of the best ones i have played so far. I had some spare money that i had to spend. I grabbed this game since it had an anime thumbnail and an interesting story. I started playing it after two weeks or so and i enjoyed it so much.

          You start the game as a dude with a cute little fella with him. (Trying to give as less spoilers as possible) You learn that the cute girl with you is a special person who can eat lies. Your ability is being able to lie just like you breathe. You learn that theres a gossip in the city and you start to investigate it with your little fella's help.

          If you are a fan of games that are JRPG-RPG's, this is a must buy game. Just grab it whenever you see it in discount, its already pretty cheap. If you got the money for it just straight up grab it.


[h1]Pros [/h1]
[list]
[*]Awesome gameplay experience
[*]Unique plot
[*]Cool and fitting music
[*]Nice graphs
[*]Multiple endings (not undertale much)
[*]Awesome artstyle
[*]Easy achievments
[*]Really well designed characters
[*]Controller support, Hurray!
[/list]

[h1]Cons [/h1]

23770192.review:
Ma copinem'a offert ce jeu, et au début je ne savais pas à quoi m'attendre.
Je l'ai laissé trainer quelques mois, puis je m'y suis attelé, et bordel la C L A Q U E.
Déjà, le jeu est relativement beau (je reviendrai dessus plus tard), ce qui fait du bien aux mirettes (surtout les animations).
L'histoire est extrêmement plaisante et même touchante par moments, avec un univers assez complet, bien que peu original aux premiers abords mais au final vraiment intéressant.
Le gameplay, quant à lui, est excellent et représente vraiment une bifle d'originalité (je ne vous en dirai pas plus par peur de vous spiler ne serait-ce qu'une minute de cette merveille).
La bande son ne marque pas les esprits, bien qu'elle soit plaisante et très agréable en tant que musique de fond.

Enfin, résumons les points forts et les points faibles de ce jeu (enfin, la paetie I étant donné que je n'ai pas encore touché aux autres) :

+ :
-Des personnages attachants
-Un scénario vachement cool que vous penserez devinez mais en fait non
-Un gameplay original
-Trois jeux, donc plusieurs histoires qui développent l'univers
-Une bande son parfois bandante

- :
-Une durée de vie assez faible (comptez environ 2h30 par partie), bien que compensée par son faible prix
-Pas de réel challenge, le jeu se boucle assez facilement
-Oublier de sauvegarder = la mort qui tue sa mère
-Les sprites et splash arts trop peu détaillés, rendant les détails difficilement reconnaissable (sexe des persos etc)

En bref, LiEat est un excellent jeu qui vaut son prix, dommage qu'il ne soit que dispo en anglais. Je le recommande fortement, vendez vos quelques skins et cartes pour ce jeu si vous pouvez.

23651340.review:
LiEat is very reminiscent of games like Earthbound, where there is a heavy emphasis on storytelling. It is split into three separate chapters with each one telling a self contained plot while all are connected by the overall arc of the main (and side) characters.

The game has an amazing and lovely art style and features some short animated scenes which are able to convey certain events better than its - still very clean and atmospheric - 16 bit (ish) graphics.

You combat different types of lies that will manifest and learn various new abilities as you level up. The combat system can feel a bit simplistic and easy at times but this is only a small issue, as the main focus of LiEat lies (no pun intended) elsewhere: the storytelling.

Even in its short length (took me roughly six hours to complete all three chapters with all trophies) the game made me care deeply about the characters and what would become of them by the end of each chapter. This also acts as a motivation to unlock the best of multiple endings of those chapters.  The soundtrack further strengthens your investment as it is perfectly set up to match the mood of each scene, which can vary drastically from happy-go-lucky to rather dark and sad.

Heart is what makes this game worth every penny and second of your time and this game has lots of it. It would be nice to see more games brimming with heart like this one. Even many of the missable side achievements are acknowledged by the game with a lighthearted pun or some trivia and therefore reward exploration. 

My only gripe is that there is not more of LiEat at this point in time, so I am hoping for a sequel in the future.

[u]In summary[/u]: A game filled with heart, characters you will be invested in, intriguing stories, clever dialogue, lovely art style, lighthearted comedy and deep feels. 
[b][u]Definitely recommended[/u][/b].


Also: Efi is just too cute and adorable so go buy this game. [u]Now[/u].

23529969.review:
Wasn't sure what to expect from this. I bought it mostly because it was on sale and because I had just finished Undertale and was hoping for something that was perhaps similar to that, or to To The Moon.

It's quick to see that the combat in this game is trivial and that didn't bother me at first because I figured the emphasis would be placed on the story telling. However the story itself is not particularly interesting. The stories (there are three of them) are very obvious, have no interesting twists, and no serious amount of drama. The game is merely about talking to / interacting with people and objects in a fixed order; there is no flexibility to the story save for in the third story where you have good/neutral/bad endings based on a minor variation at the very end.

I don't really care for the relationship between the main characters, which is something the writer was obviously shooting for. Despite many "d'aww" moments of how cute they look together in some of the art, none of the relationships between characters is particularly deep.

In the end you get a game with neither interesting combat nor an interesting story. There are "puzzles" that are essentially non-puzzles, as they are obvious to the point of not being worth including in the game, and I would have liked to see something more challenging. The stories also tend to be rather rushed, and some of the explanations / motivations behind some of the stories are rather lackluster, in a "and it was all a dream" kind of cliche way (without being that particular trope).

The art and music are fine, but I would recommend either Undertale or To The Moon if you want a similar experience with a more memorable story.

23515428.review:
Let me start this review by saying I was lukewarm to ambivalent about getting this game at the time I got it... I just wanted something cheap with achievements and trading cards.  The description was slightly interesting, but didn't really draw me in.
THIS GAME IS NOW ONE OF MY FAVORITE STEAM GAMES!

After playing through this game completely, I have to say that it was amazingly good!
The graphics are not anything to shout about, being comparable to NES games or Greyfox or the Elements series.
HOWEVER, the STORY was in-depth and engaging, and VERY imaginative!  WELL worth the price of admission!

Also, unlike many similar RPG's on Steam, this game has smooth and responsive controls (no clunk, yay!), and no bugs that I've noticed (there are probably bugs somewhere, but none that a casual gamer will notice)!

If you want a fun, retro-ish NES-style RPG game that is cheap, has trading cards, and achievements, GET THIS GAME!
If you want a game with an imaginative, interesting story, GET THIS GAME!
If you want a game to gift to a friend that likes old-school RPGs, GET THIS GAME!

This game is middling eay to beat normally.
HOWEVER... if you want to go GOD-mode (G.reatly O.verpowered D.readnought), each of the three games has "Legendary Weapons" hidden somewhere.  The excellent guides on Steam's guide page can direct you to them.

The game is cut into 3 separate games, each with 10 achievements (some of which are pretty funny!  (Happosai achievement FTW!).  None of them are bugged, as far as I can tell, and each chapter is pretty short.  Even shorter if you keep spamming enter and skip all the text, I suppose, but you REALLY want to read the story in this, it's REALLY GOOD!
You don't carry anything over from "chapter" to "chapter", each one is started as a blank slate.  Leveling is quick and easy, with a minimum of grinding involved.
After each "chapter" is complete, you'll appear in an "after-game room" with pics and a sound test book.  Make an extra save here just for fun, and exit to go to the next chapter!
In the last chapter, there are 3 endings, each with a separate achievement... good, bad, and ug... erm, neutral!

As mentioned before, specifics are covered by several well-made guides in the community hub.

23228404.review:
通关撒花：食谎者，实际上是3部作品的合集，讲述了3个短小却治愈的故事。日式RPG游戏，带有一点解谜元素，童话式的画风，好听的BGM，偶有暗黑但却不失温馨，萌点十足，打动人心。

（游戏测试可能会取消，以下方法曾经有效）调出游戏自带繁体中文的具体步骤：

1、steam设置里面选择参与测试，这是前提。
2、在库里选中游戏并右键，属性里面选择测试，然后改成参与测试。成功以后游戏开始更新，其实就是下载语言包。
3、继续右键属性，选择浏览本地文件，会看到出现了一个CN文件夹，代表语言包已经下好，点开会看到里面有LiEat1、2、3。
4、从文件夹里直接运行游戏会出现乱码，下载一个AppLocale即可解决，它是一款由微软出品的解决乱码的软件。
5、AppLocale的使用方法：浏览里面选中需要打开的游戏文件，然后目标语言改成繁体中文即可。

虽然看似复杂，但只是因为菲菲写的比较细，核心就是要下载AppLocale，大小只有1M而已，如果其他游戏出现乱码也可以用这个软件解决。存在不足：游戏时间不会记录在steam上，也不会解锁成就，按F12不是截图而是返回主菜单，仅仅是让玩家更好的体验剧情。游戏流程很短，玩家完全可以体验剧情之后再速通一遍解锁成就和截图，CG画风非常华丽。

既然是日式RPG，随时注意与环境互动是必然的，也许在某个奇怪的地方就会隐藏着惊喜。解谜很简单，注意与NPC的对话内容即可。结局不唯一，注意多存一些档，为了打出一个满意的结局读档重来是很正常的。三部曲网上都有攻略，请放心食用。

帅气的男性欺诈师与龙族的萌萝莉，不停的变装和使用化名，在一个又一个小镇上旅行，你不想知道他们经历了怎样的故事吗？

23226450.review:
Cool and cute art, engaging story divided into episodes of sorts, multiple characters... Not much in this game not to like, really. I almost feel bad for letting it sit in my library for a few months before finally actually playing it... I also almost feel bad that it was so short, as I really enjoyed it and played through the whole thing in a single sitting. So yeah, a great title.

LiEat isn't a very long game, as it took me less than 4 hours to 100%. There isn't really any grinding involved like in many RPGs, so that should be a fairly accurate time it should take most people, I suppose. There was some extra exploring to do, but not all that much. The game is definitely story-centered, though the concept in the fights, where you fight and eat lies is a pretty fun and interesting idea.

I'd suggest just buying the game and going in blind, as it's pretty short and it's nicer to find out everything throughout the story and dialogue rather than read about it.

If you need just a small taste of what's to come, the story is basically following a man and this very young dragon-girl as they go around from place to place (well, just one place per episode, and there are 3 of them, but still) and the man basically works as a detective, with the girl helping him out with her ability to see and literally eat lies.

If I have to say one negative thing, the... 'puzzles' in the last episode were a bit frustrating, as they had absolutely zero challenge to them, making them a bit frustrating — but they included dialogue and more story-telling as you progressed in them, so it wasn't too bad.

23224375.review:
Technically this is three games, the entire LiEat trilogy.  Each game is a relatively short and sweet rpg with a light fantasy-detective vibe.  The art is cute or disturbing as the narrative demands.  The writing is what really sells these games, though.  All of the characters are engaging and dynamic, the story of each game drags you in, answers your core questions while still leaving some backstory up to your imagination.  I don't have much background in music theory, but I found all of the songs nice to listen to and non-annoying, so there's that.  Those who enjoy stories about growing up, healing after traumatic experiences, and found families will most definitely enjoy these games.

If, however, you're super not into anime-esque graphics, or getting very little explanation for your story elements, then this is probably not the game series for you.  Also, the battles aren't particularly challenging, so if you're more into game mechanics than story this going to be another no-go for you.  Additionally, I didn't think that any of the answers to the mysteries were particularly tough to figure out way before the characters, but that might just be me.

Overall, I heartily recommend the LiEat series for those who favor story over gameplay.

23194459.review:
LiEat is another type of JRPG upon the hundreds released already on the steam store page, but what makes this one stand out? Well, to list a few, they would be the cost, art-style/design, and a simple, yet original plot. The game is seperated into three stories/games to play. You start off the trilogy playing as a character named Leo whom's past is mysterious and has multiple aliases. While your little partner, Efi. is a very carefree and happy young girl who's special ability to eat lies may bring more trouble than asked for. The game overall is a very nice small enjoyable JRPG, but may fall short in 'super deep' character development(You shouldn't expect this in a 2-3 hour game, 4-6 if you're a completionist). My main complants about the game are about how short this wonderful little game is, (hope for a sequel? Most likely not. T_T) and the leveling within the game. Once you level high enough(or find the special items hidden in-game.), even the main bosses' attacks will do a massive heaping 1 dmg, and doesn't really make it challenging, or as fun. However, even with these kind of mini complaints, the game is still amazing and I highly reccomend this to any RPG-lover and those new to the genre. 

tl;dr: Good short JRPG, loli-dragon sidekick, cheap.

23048482.review: This game is a fun experience I'm sure the general audience could get in to.  Each story is told like a fairy tale and each character is okay.  There isn't much depth in this game sadly.  You mainly play this game for the story since fights can only be encountered at certain times.  The battle mechanics are okay for the few fights you're going to be fighting.  There are no shops in these games (because this game actually contains 3 stories) so you'll have to be more explorative when wandering around to find certain things like weapons, armor, or consumables.  Since this game is story driven it would be expected to have decent writing and aesthetics.  This is true.  The story as simple as it was had me hooked.  The over arcing mystery of the main female's existence interested me to no end and I believe the music and art compliments everything well.  Gameplay and most cutscenes are in a pixel style and it looks nice, but there are a few cinematic cutscenes that are in an anime style and they look nice.  Overall I would say that this game is great, but don't expect something on the scale of Final Fantasy, Fire Emblem, or just a licensed RPG title.  I recommend going into this just with the thought of having a fun and simple adventure.

23046305.review:
I normally make stupid joke reviews, but this game deserves a serious review as to why you need this game.

LiEat is a short, indie, RPG-maker game about Efina: The lie eating dragon, and Theo: a conartist who watches over Efi. The game has three parts that come with the single, $2.99 USD purchase. Think of it as three different arcs of a story, just separated to show a jump in time. 

The characters in this game are fantastic. Every character you meet is unique and memorable, even if you only meet them once, they even have their own profile to discribe them. 

The music is fantastic. Even if the main battle theme "Liar" is remixed in each part, it still sounds wonderful.

This game is not difficult, nor is it meant to be, considering you can find weapons that raise your attack to 500 and your level will never exceed 20. But that's ok. Because this game is a short, fun game not intending to test your full Atlus game skills.

So why should you get this game? Because it's short, cheap, fun, and good. I don't know what else to say, just get it, you won't regret it.

With the reasons stated above, in the 2016 Steam Awards under "we didn't think of everything", you should write in "simple, but Beautiful" and nominate this game.

For being a short experience, LiEat is an incredibly vibrant, fun game. It's cut into three short chapters, and you should be able to get through each chapter in a matter of a few hours. It's a unique way to handle a game, but one that makes it fun to binge play in small sessions. I've already played through each chapter, am currently going through to get all the achievements, and plan to play it for friends in the near future. 

Each of the chapters has a unique story with colorful characters. Most won't be seen in all three chapters, other than the two main characters -- our alias-changing conman and Effie the dragon. However they'll definitely leave lasting impressions and are incredibly unique, so you'll never forget which characters go to what story. 

I highly reccommend this wonderful title! It's been loads of fun, and has shot up to be one of my favorite games in my library. If you have a few hours and a few dollars to spare, why not pick up this wonderful game? It'll pass the time and give you a great experience in the process.

22916084.review:
For my regions equivalent of 2.45 USD, I believe it is worth picking this up (or downloading rather). The story is short, about 6-8 hours depending on how you play it. That is 2-3 hours of entertainment per dollar, I'm going to be honest and say I wouldn't have bought this for more before, and I am glad it is this cheap.

The story (or stories) are good, if only a little too focused on lies being bad. The ending was a little cheesy and weird, but not bad. It could just as well have been a VN, though i am glad it's not. The F4 button is your friend. This feels like a game that was solely developed by artists and writers, because it is not fun working with the game window.

I recomend it if for people looking for a short but sweet story. If you are looking for a combat oriented JRPG type game, then this is not for you (altough you are likely to know that already). This is absolutley worth it at that price, and I am looking forward to a similar game that is a lot more fleshed out in terms of story and tec. 

Arbitrary point scale: 8/10

22887725.review:
The game itself is split on three chapters, where you play as both Efina, a young dragon whose power is seeing and eating lies and her "papa". 
Each chapter features a different story where you learn more and more about these characters and how they feel about the other and some of the game lore.

Pros:
-Interesting story.
-Not hard to achieve 100% achievements.
-Charming characters.
-The soundtrack is nice.
-It's cheap.

Cons:
-The game is kind of short (Around 6 hours even if you get all achievements)
-The game is mostly story-driven, so if you're interested in the battle system or such, you will feel kind of disappointed.

In a nutshell: This is an amazing game for its price so you should definitely buy it.

22755257.review: This is such a nice little RPG, probably the best 3 bucks i ever spent. There's three seperate stories here, and having only beaten first and second one, I cannot wait to find out what happens in the third. The focus here was really on the characters and the events that occur around them in their hunt for information. The battle system is turn based, and works well for how simple it is, although it can get repetitive. The "enemies" you'll be fighting are lies, but you get to decide if you want to get into a fight or not by deciding if it is a lie or the truth, so there's a kind of detective aspect to it, as well. For example, the area that the lie is in will probably have characters with diologue, if you talk to them it might give you insight as to why that lie is there, or who told it and why, or if it's even a lie. There are many, many implied things happening behind the scenes that aren't directly told to the player, and plenty of little tidbits of information and extra stuff/diologue to be found in the small but interesting areas. Most of my time was spent walking around clicking on everything and anything that had the slightest chance of being intereactable because I was so interested in the world and the people in it. Also, the soundtrack is absolutely fantastic, each track being a pretty much perfect fit for the area you'll hear it in. It's so worth it, I promise.

22736506.review:
Pros:
-Fantastic art
-Great soundtrack
-Very likeable characters
-Plenty of nice easter eggs
-Cheap

The cons can hardly be considered cons, it mostly depends on what you're looking for out of a game.

Cons:
-Battles are repetitive and easy
-Aside from one or two instances, puzzles are rather easy

Conclusion:
LiEat is probably the best $3 you'll ever spend on a game. Extremely easy to hop right into and complete in only a few hours; enough content and achievements to allow some replay value, and a very likeable cast with great character designs. If you're looking for a casual, cheap JRPG to keep you occupied for a few hours, buy it. If you're a JRPG fan at all, buy it. Really, regardless of taste you should just buy it, especially if it ever goes on sale (I bought my copy for probably $0.99). Overall one of the better JRPG experiences I've had recently.

22717705.review:
After beating this game and each of his 3 chapters, I can say that this is the most splendid and beautiful game I have played in a long while.

It sent me back to the era when I used to download and play RPG maker games like Misao, Ao oni or Mad Father.

The art style is beautiful, the soundtrack is perfect and the story is just magnificent...
This game is so good that I wish that one day everyone will be able to play a sequel, I know this game is great and that a lot of people would play it.

Okay... now to the serious stuff; the game itself is about 5 hours long, or 6 if you want to get every achievement.
The game has a simple fighting system that but it's really entertaining, there might not be many enemies to fight beside lies and some bosses, but the fighting system it's not that important, what's important here is the wonderful and gorgeous story, the story is very interesting and sometimes it hits you hard in the feels.

If I had to rate this game it would be a solid [b]10/10[/b]

[h1]Pros:[/h1]

• The art style is amazing. 
• The fighting system is very basic but entertaining.
• Soundtrack is very relaxing and totally well made
• The price is perfect, basically, 1$ for each 3 of the games.
• The animations are short but really great.
• The puzzles are really good even if there's about one per game.
• The characters are pretty interesting and beautiful.
• The game is pretty light, you can install it in about 5 to 10 minutes and you will be rewarded with 5-6 hours of gameplay.
• The facial expressions are very cute and well made.
• Very funny achievements with great references.
• Cute


[h1][u][b]Spoilers Ahead, you have been warned:[/b][/u][/h1]
[b] These spoilers will be about the game's endings so I really warn you, the endings are so beautiful that if you haven't beaten the game yet you should definitely not read the cons, I am just trying to say that the endings are way too good and you should not get spoiled, go discover it yourself, its really worth it![/b]

Cons:

• [spoiler]I don't think this is a con but rather more of a wish;The game leaves you a massive cliffhanger on the good ending, by now the bad ending already shows us that Leo is taken by the lies and becomes evil, Efina still follows him and promises him that one day she will become powerful enough to eat his lies.
The neutral ending wich is even sadder than the bad one ends up with Efina being way too weak (Under or at level 11) to eat Leo's lies, thus having to use all of her power to protect him thus making her perish but saving the life of Leo, wich made her happy.
The good ending is just heartwarming, Efina is strong enough ( level 12 or higher ) to eat all of Leo's lies and Leo is capable of talking to Cyril to confess that everything he did was to protect them. Cyril proceeds to leave with his brothers ( Not counting Leo ) and takes off via helicopter thus leaving Leopold and Efina in the rooftop, they both move on together to the next adventure...[/spoiler]

Final Note:
This game is amazing and worth every single penny, I give it a solid 10/10 coming very very deep from my heart...
Even if the game's ending is a massive cliffhanger that probably left some people in despair for a sequel, I guess it's not a bad idea to wait and have some patience, personally, I wish that this game gets a sequel anytime soon...

I saw this game, and I shrugged it off because it looked like a simple RPG Maker-ish game. So I ignored it for months.

Then I kept noticing this game for one reason or another, maybe because steam keeps recommending it to me or maybe because dragon girls are pretty cool?

Months latered I ended up succumbing and getting this $3.29 (CDN) gem. I'm sure glad my curiosity got the better of me. While short, it's a very captivating and interesting story. My only wish is that it should have had 1 or 2 more installments before the finale. I felt the story scaled too quickly from episodic mystery's to the big mystery behind Efi's 'papa'.

Just don't ever buy it thinking it will have a good combat system. It's really barebones and exists only to assist the narrative. Said narrative is the only reason to experience this game.

22607422.review:
[i]The best $3.29 (CDN) I ever spent on Steam. LiEat is seriously good.[/i]

Basically you're a wandering vagabond with a loli dragon girl who can eat lies. Using this power they solve mysteries and find out more about themselves along the way. Game is seperated into 3 short parts or "chapters" and can take a good 8-10 hours if you interact with everything and aim for most of the achivements.

[h1]Pros[/h1]
+ Fast, smooth, responsive gameplay & controls
+ Music & Ambiance really fits and sets the mood (Bonus: Soundtrack included in Steam>Library>Music)
+ Well crafted story and lore
+ The pixels, CGs, cutscenes & character portraits all fit together well and create a unique and charming style
+ Lots of hidden dialogue and stuff to interact with + achievements

[h1]Cons[/h1]
- Combat starts to get a little repetitive after a while
- The hidden Legendary weapons are super OP if you "accidentally" find them (I found all 3 by accident)

Overall, I'd definitely recommend LiEat, it's short, unique, charming and sweet.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=667351001

NOTE: With my reviews, I tend to do the pros/cons thing, because it's simple and straight to the point rather than paragraphs which someone might not have the time to read.

22388116.review:
I came across this game as somewhat of a "recommendation". It looked pretty cute, and it supposedly had a good storyline. So, I picked it up, and I can say I'm quite impressed.

To start off, the game's story revolves around two characters : Efi and Leo. Leo is a man who does nothing but spew lies, and Efi is a young dragon that turns lies into monsters and eats them. Over the course of three chapters, smaller stories involving legends, oddities and supernatural events are laid out in a mostly linear path that prompts the player to interact with objects or NPCs to progress.

The game is strongly story-driven, as the RPG element is fairly lackluster, though the way in which battles are introduced is rather unique and serves the story (the main focus of the game) well. Essentially, Efi is used as a "lie detector" and must defeat and consume manifested lies as Leo solves a "mystery" surrounding the abnormal events. Most points of the game are rather cheery and quirky while others tend to be a bit unnerving, though overall the game gives off a light-hearted tone while delivering a tangible plot. Regardless, I thought the story was pretty solid, which is what makes this game what it is.

As far as art and music go, the artstyle is all very cute-sy and pixel-styled, and my only complaint is that during combat some numbers are difficult to read (though it isn't that large of a problem since battles generally exist to progress plot elements and serve as little more than button mashers). The soundtrack is very nice in my opinion; the themes all fit the art very well and while a bit on the simple side, do generally fit the situation.

So there you have it; LiEat: A small story-driven mini-RPG. Came for an RPG, got a Kinetic Visual Novel.

22343584.review:
LiEat is a fun and short game that you may play to pass time. However, do not take this game too seriously or expect the most out of it.

Pros: 
~Great graphics in terms of character design and setting
~Lovable character personality
~You become more and more engaged with the game when you get past LiEat Part I
~Cute
~Entertaining, unique, interesting

Cons:
~Very little direction, you will spend a lot if not most of LiEat walking around meaninglessly! 
~Ending conditions are awful for LiEat Part III
~Semi-amateurish 
~Probably one of the most predictable games I've played in a while

-Indirect Spoilers-

LiEat was very light hearted yet had detective/mystery elements that made you want to play more to see what type of plot twist the game had cooked up for you. Although this is great for early-midgame of each part, you find yourself disappointed as the endings are pretty much the most obvious paths you could even imagine. Hell, red herrings are supposed to lead the player to believe that one character is the culprit, only an UNEXPECTED person to be the crime doer! This game doesn't do that. Also the ending condition for LiEat III was petty. Basically the game forces you to check around with little direction for a clue, consequently the player rechecks a lot of thing. If you check a certain thing more than once, bam, you get a bad ending without the slightest warning. 

-end spoiler- 

Despite the disappointing endings, I recommend this game because it entertained me most of the time, which you know, is the point of games! You'll really love the characters, and it will probably make you smile. The story is interesting and makes you want to know more.

22304903.review:
LiEat is a series containing three short rpgs, featuring Leo, a traveling conman, and his companion and somewhat adopted daughter Efina. At the start of each chapter the two have arrived in a new location after assuming new identities, and are almost immediately thrown into some chaos as a local legend comes to life. By making use of Efi’s ability to materialize and consume lies, the two unravel the tales of the people and places they come across. In each chapter we’re also given a better understanding of Leo’s character and what Efi means to him.

In this world there are humans (who often do not look human by our standards) and dragons. Dragons are born from the wishes of humans, and their powers are shaped by the nature of the human’s wish. While I felt like I was presented with just a slice or two from an entire pizza, I did find the tidbits about the world juicy to nibble on. The character designs are inventive, and the colors used set different tones for each of the three games. 

The soundtrack makes use of tinkling music boxes, bells, harpsichords, accordions, piano and more to create somewhat classical-inspired tunes. It’s not an in-your-face soundtrack but some of the tunes are quite catchy and most are great for the scenes they’re used in. 

While there may be some confusion about where to go and who to talk to in order to trigger the next event, the areas are small so being lost for any significant period of time is impossible. Each game lasts maybe an hour to an hour and a half, most likely less for anyone who has played the free version before (which are still out there, by the way, the Steam version is here just to support the dev with a few bucks). About the only thing I didn’t like about LiEat is that there isn’t more of it. Okay, okay, if I have to force out something negative, it’s that the battles offer no strategy or challenge at all. They’re more a means to an end, and the game would likely be just as good if they were replaced with something else or removed entirely. 

When all is said and done, I’m left impressed by the colorful world and some of the especially nice touches that you typically wouldn't expect from little indie rpgs like this. Despite the short length, I felt attached to the characters. Hopefully there will be more entries into the LiEat world.

22301958.review:
LiEat is definitely one of my top favorites as of now. Its got that same kind of charm that games like Undertale and OFF have. The gameplay is lacking, but the storyline is fantastic and more than makes up for this. It comes with 3 episodes, all of which can be completed within a few hours. 

The story itself is dark however, there are plenty of funny and cute moments that lighten the game up a bit. 

My only gripes about the game are that its pretty short, the levels are tiny, and that the gameplay isn't as deep as it could be. For instance, theres no use for money in the game, yet you earn it. Even something small like adding a tiny little vendor somewhere would make it feel more developed. The money feels like it was just tacked on last minute. HOWEVER you really don't need to buy anything since the game is so short and you find plenty of healing items and such. If they decide to release more LiEat, I would love to see this added if they extended the game and joined all the episodes into one bigger game with more areas to explore. It felt slightly claustrophobic being in such a small venue.

For its price, I'd HIGHLY reccomend it. I think I'd be willing to pay a little more to be honest. I found myself wishing I didn't finish it by the time I got to the end and every bit of it is enjoyable. Its easily a 4.8/5 and i'm looking forward to seeing what the developer comes out with next.

LiEat is a [i]truly beautiful game[/i] with an interesting plotline and set of characters. This game comes with all three LiEat games and is definitely worth the $2.99. As a League of Legends fan (boooo, says everyone...) I've come to use this game to play in queue because Rito Gaems has awful queue times. I've only played two games out of three, but I really, really enjoyed the two. I'm looking forward to completing the third!

Here are many pros of LiEat:
- Absolutely adorable characters
- Very immersive story
- Soundtrack for you
- The music and game pauses when you minimize the screen/open something else (Perfect if you're waiting in some kind of queue for a MOBA such as League...)
- Three games in one, little client
- Quite a bit of replay value if you enjoy the games (100% achievement)
- There are trading cards, backgrounds, and emoticons!
- YOU CAN SAVE [B]WHENEVER[/B] YOU WANT

...although, you might want to consider these [b]very few cons[/b]:
- If you're a fast reader, you're going to get through these games quick. Luckily, as I stated before, there's a lot of replay value if you find this game fun.
- The game will not full screen, it's a rather small window
- It's great that you can save whenever you want...but you have to save constantly. You never know if a little lie is gonna wipe the ♥♥♥♥ out of your HP leaving you with 20HP...and you've run out of small candies to eat. And then wowie! you have to battle someone else. RIP Leo + Efi.

Overall, this is a game I rate 10/10 because who doesn't love small dragon children? Hope you found this review a little bit helpful. :)
