22150959.review:
Please read the full review, this includes controls to the game that some players might not understand if they haven't fully explored them on their own.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Well, the game is definitely fun. I've played it enough to know a bit about it. I definitely enjoy the adorable art style of the game and how it was made. It's very well thought out when it comes to the story. For the most part it's about a con man and his dragon girl, Efina. Efina is abnormal compared to the other dragons in the world, as she has a different diet that revolves around, 'lies', lies are physical beings created when a character in the game lies. It's your job to determine which is a lie, and which is the truth.


Pros:
-Really fun
-Adorable
-Great story, it's super fun to play
-Characters act human like
-Entering homes with the space bar instead of just walking in - This feels more natural to me than just walking into some place as if the door automatically opens for you.. I like it more.
-Features a minor use of the mouse. Not many games do this, I kind of like it.

Cons:
-Issues figuring out some controls, for newer players (like myself)
-Fighting is a tad bit too easy in the beginning.. - Gets a BIT harder, by introducing something like an eight on two battle..
-Some issues arise with the music, making it sound kind of.. Troublesome, and problematic to want and listen to. The looping situation isn't all that good, and definitely could've been better.
-Clunky use of the Fn keys, it's all scattered around.
-Problems with the FPS change.. Not really made for it
-Sometimes when holding a button for a full second will cause you to instantly skip text you may have wanted to read..
-Kind of throws you into the game.. Without instructions
-English translation is still having some issues, but so far it's getting there, example is at the top.. It doesn't translate well... Or at all in this matter.
-Really short if you rush

Question:

- Why isn't there a WSAD implementation into the game? Alongside the Up, down, left, right arrows? Kind of like Undertale has? It's possible to do..
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Now upon further investigation there's a few things not notted that I kind of wish were in the game fully as an, 'option' setting. See, the thing about the options is that they aren't fully labled. They utilize the Fn comands, such as F1, F2, etc. Now, not all are used but I will list the ones that are used. To help newer players figure out how to change around some things. Also not included inside of the game in any way is instructions on how the game plays

Keys that don't do anything:
- F1
- F2
- F3
- F6
- F7
- F9
- F11

Keys that have use:

F4 - You start with the default screen which can be too small to some users. Or too big. Press it once at the default size, and it'll grow larger. Press it again, it'll become small. Once more and you're back at the default screen size.

F5 - The game itself runs at 60 Frames Per Sec. By default this is the source frames you're going to get to determine how fast the game plays. By pressing it once, the game will lower the FPS to 30 Frames Per Sec. Pressing again will lower it to 15 FPS. If you press it again, the game will bring it back up to 60 FPS, and it'll be the default speed.

F8 - If you don't use the default FPS setting made by Steam to determine how many frames you're on. The game has a built in FPS counter that's VERY accurate. It works the same as the default FPS setting in Steam, and is just as accurate.

F10 - If you HATE the default screen sizes and would rather play it in full screen, the game can be played in full screen by pressing F10. The resolution isn't bad, but it looks a bit better and makes it easier to see when using it.. Not sure why this key wasn't binded to the same one as F4. But, it still helps if you want it, just press F10 to go out of full screen.

F12 - By default Steam utilizes a screenshot mechanic that allows you to capture games, this is useful if you wanna screenshot it.

ESC/X/Backspace - The escape key, X key and the Backspace button are all used to open your menu, this will allow you to swap items and view other things in your inventory.

Space Bar - Allows you to go through text, press it and it'll go to the next screen.

UP, DOWN, LEFT, RIGHT arrow keys - All used for movement. Different from the WSAD movement, this game uses that.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

So if I was to rate the game as a game developer himself, I'd give at at least a 9.5/10. Now, I'm not one to call games out on what they are and if they have issues. But upon reading reviews, this is supposedly the first game made by this indie dev. It's a REALLY nice game despite the issues. I definitely enjoy playing it, and so does my lover. I convinced them to get it to play with me, they REALLY like it as well. They notice the issues, but it's definitely not that bad.

I would really recommend the game because it's.. Nice, it's a very fun game, the character designs are interesting. I also should mention that there's use of drawn out scenes, which might I add are absolutely great to look at, it fits well and expresses differences in the characters. There was a use of one scene where one of the character's hair was blowing in the wind, and I thought it looked great. Overall. It's fun, it's clunky, but it's really nice. 

If you want a game that's short, but has a nice background to it, with interesting characters, adorable moments, some weird moments, and extra stuff to it, I definitely reccomend it.

Now, this is mostly a review from someone who has played only the first part out of three, but.. I can tell this is worth it by how much time I'm spending just playing it. Try not to rush the dialogue, or else you'll miss out on where you need to go. There ARE some spots.. Where you have to figure out where to go on your own, but it isn't too hard, search all the houses you know that characters are in, you'll find the next spot you need to go. Make sure to talk to them to get more dialogue. 

Remember, this is only a standpoint of me currently, and I don't think you'll be disappointed. The game is definitely worth more than $2.99. To me at least, it could be at least $3.99, but.. $2.99 for this game is a steal nonetheless. If it was longer I'd say bump it more, but I really hope this dev comes out with even more content in the future and continues to update and create a better translation to the game. 

TL;DR
Game is great, read above for controls, definitely is different and it's really fun.

22111626.review:
A very short and sweet little story!  It's hard to find a good JRPG that can be completed in a sitting or two, especially one that keeps you guessing with every moment!  

The battle system is fairly basic, but it really isn't the focus of the game.  The story, however, is the main attraction.  The first charpter is fairly slow, but it establishes a good brackdrop for the next two.  Chapter two starts to thread some things together, making the overarching theme of "lying will always catch up to you..." come together a bit more clearly.  The last chapter deviates from the first two by diving into the main crux of the story almost immediately!  Great endings, too!  Some of them can be a bit tricky to piece together, but they are easily found with a bit of digging.

This is the first game I bought and played through almost immediately after I got it in a very long time!  I highly recommend this to anyone that is looking for a good short story and a fan to the JRPG genre!

The main characters, Efi and Theo, have an interesting relationship, the nature of which starts mysterious and becomes more clear over the course of the three chapters in a very satisfying way. While fairly short, each chapter has new character graphics (Theo and Efi recieve makeovers) and multiple endings to find. It took me a couple of hours for each chapter, playing casually and exploring.

A note about the gameplay: The game utilizes JRPG style battles which are quick and easy to win. In my estimation, the battles are not there to present a challenge but rather to support the central conceit of the game ([spoiler]Efi causes lies to manifest in the real world, which she then eats.[/spoiler]) without getting in the way of the storytelling. If you only enjoy video games that challenge, then you should be warned to approach this one with a more open mind or to move on to something else.

I definitely recommend this game for it's original story, great characters, and adorable yet dark aesthetic.

[list]
[*][h1]ストーリー[/h1]
詐欺師のレオ（仮名）は嘘を食べるというドラゴン、エフィーナと共に各地を旅しています。
2人が辿り着いた街はヴァンパイアの伝説が伝えられていました。

しかしそこには「大嘘」が隠されていたのでした。それも街ぐるみで隠している重大な嘘。
2人はその嘘を暴くことが出来るのか。

独特の雰囲気、かわいいグラフィックとドット絵。
終始ダークで不思議な雰囲気を醸し出す街。
上のビデオでも見てもらえたほうが早いです。
その魅力に引き込まれることでしょう。

[*][h1]サウンド[/h1]
BGM全曲書き下ろし。
１作あたり９曲ほどでしょうか。
全てフリーなのでいつでも聞けます。
クリア後のおまけ部屋みたいなところでも聞けます。
不思議な雰囲気にマッチしていていつの間にか引き込まれてしまいます。
これも上のビデオを見てもらえば。
[/list]

10/10

21874838.review:
This game is cute.

The game is split into 3 seperate games in the same world. It's an rpg about a mysterious con man and his little dragon girl, Efina, who has the ability to eat people's lies. They live in a world inhabited by "dragons" and they go from town to town solving problems acting as detectives( since Efina is basically a lie detector), all the while the man sells info for cash. Humans and dragons have a rough relationship with eachother. Dragons are sometimes seen as slaves, however they are allowed to be in positions of power and allowed to live among humans.
The "dragons" in this game aren't dragons in the traditional sense. They are still born from eggs and each can breath fire, but they are human in appearance and each is born from wishes. They each have a special ability based off of the nature of the wish.

The characters in this game are likable enough. The con man, who gets several diferent names throughout, is your typical rogue with a heart of gold who still wants to help people but usually at a price. He tells lies, but with good intentions. Efina is a cute, naive, dragon-girl who sees the con man as her father. Her power is to eat lies as mentioned above. She wants to help her father stop lying one day.
The side characters are mostly just there for world building and to help Efina understand her powers. There's the police force captain, Captain Neill, who is also a dragon and he is just your generic captain who is stern and helps people. The vice captain, Brett (also a dragon), is a little more angsty and hates humans. Each game has its own set of characters for that game's story obviously. 

The art style is consistant and cute. It's pixel art with a chibi look to it and It's styalized in a sort of fancy gothic way. Everything has a dark outline and it's just nice to look at. The two main character get diferent outfits for each story and they fit pretty well with where they are. The music is pleasant and fits with the setting. However, it's not very memorable by itself. There is also a problem with the music and the cutscenes. When a custscene plays the music will often just stay the same or keep playing even as the cutscene is happening. So something might be happening in the cutscene but the music doesn't help portray it very well.

There is also something to be said about the rpg elements. You get the basic stuff (switching items, leveling, looting, etc.), and you fight enemies. But the enemies aren't random encounters, they often just appear as you progress the plot. There are enemies that you can fight over and over however to level up. But there really isn't much need to, as you just get the levels you need during the story anyway. You get rewarded with money from winning battles. But as far as I can tell, there is nothing to use the money on so it's ultimately pointless.

The game isn't very difficult and is more just about the story. There are multiple endings to each game depending on what you do. To get each ending you just have to do one or two things diferently. There is a detective element as mentioned above, where you have to figure out wether lies are actually lies or if they are the truth, but there really isn't a punishment for guessing wrong so you can just guess until you get the right answer. You can also just find items by looking around that can make you completely overpowered to futher drop the difficulty. 

The game is also very short. Each story can be beat in just under two hours at most. You could probably get a little bit more time out of it to get all the endings and achievments, but you just need to use an old save to do that unless you want to play through it again.

Honestly though it's an alright game for the price. Short and sweet, not to difficult, and just plain cute. It does have flaws just mechanically but nothing that gets in the way. If you have a few hours to spend I'd say give it a try.

[h1]A hidden gem discovered by chance[/h1]

The trailer got me totally captivated, the price was low and I told myself [i]"Why not?"[/i]
I have then discovered that this game was available for free on the maker's page.
What was my reaction? None! These were the 2.99 € I've spent most gladly in my life!
LiEat is a really touching short series of games with an original art style, music and a rather deep character-focused story.
I'm really happy to have found it on Steam, so I could support the author of this really beautiful gem. It was since playing [b]Ib[/b] that I was looking for something which could give me the same warm feeling, while being deep at the same time :3 If you don't know it, well, it's not on Steam, but you should check it out!

I've found only a couple cons:
* in the first chapter, music does not loop well;
* you can enter doors from the side of the houses;
* combat is neither deep nor really interesting, but it's well justified storywise.

My advice is... just forget about the free version and buy it! Game makers like this deserve all our contribution :)

"Lies is like a box of chocolates. You never if they contain reasons or ugliness."
       (这句话是从下面的评测里借用的,虽不是原创但我觉得很契合主题就拿来用了,抱歉.)

       本作是一款讲述骗子爸爸和能力是吃掉谎言的龙女儿旅途故事的RPG.剧情紧凑引人入胜,虽然不知道其他人读起来如何,但至少对于我而言,无论是画风,人物设计,剧情抑或配乐都称得上佳作;顺便一提,游戏引擎是WOLF,免费的.

       售价15RMB,即使全额购买也不算贵更不会亏的一个价格.
       希望你们喜欢.
       Enjoy yourself.

The actual mechanics of the game are to put it mildly simplistic, with combat being mostly of a token nature with more effort often required if you want to lose fights for achievements than to win them, and a great deal of time is spent poking random corners of rooms to see if there is candy (or clues) there.

21730718.review:
Those of you who are looking for a shorter pros/cons list, scroll to the bottom.



Lieat is an RPG with three chapters to it, all about a con artist and a lie-eating dragon who met him after hatching and is now following him around. During these chapters they'll come across challenges that ends up with having to to do some detective work, which results in going into battle to eat the lies in people's alibis. Along the way they'll be some recurring characters you'll learn more about and about the world around you. I'll try to keep this short and as spoiler-free as possible.

[b] The story [/b]
The story, having three chapters, is actually a lot shorter than most RPGs. Each chapter has about the length of one short story, and yet is still capable of keeping you wanting to know what comes next in the further chapters. All while the story goes on, the game manages to inform you about the world and characters without falling into the pit of having too many exposition dumps. I mean, sure, they do have some, but doesn't all games at least have a few?

[b] The characters [/b]
The characters are another big part of the game, giving the recurring characters life and background quickly, and still giving you immersion. Most of the characters are quite endearing, and has some quirky trait to make them stand out. I would agree that the game does have some holes in certain supporting characters, but these characters usually last only as long as the chapter.

[b] The mechanics [/b]
The battles and mechanics are very barebone, with nothing special about them. In fact, most of the battles are just ways to move the story(thanks to all the enemies being physical manifestations of lies, and beating means said lie-eating dragon eats them). This doesn't mean the combat is bad, however. It's just very average and short-lived. Although the lack of grinding or needing a good strategy can be a bonus if you are more interested into the story rather than combat.

[b] The soundtrack [/b]
The soundtrack is actually pretty good to listen to as well, espcially if you enjoy the sort of piano-and-bell sort of music. Add the fact that the most recent update to this game has let you listen to them through steam's music player makes the sounds track another bonus to this game.

[b] Side notes [/b]
Here I'll be listing some bonus points, in case you care. The endings are mostly there to set yourself up to see the next chapter, but saying anything more would risk spooling the game. There's also bad endings, but luckily, you won't automatically run into them so long as you don't do something stupid like run into a back alley in the middle of the night. I also enjoyed the achievements, especially the ones that shame you for taking items that don't do anything out of people's houses just for the sake of taking them. And yes, there are trading cards. 
Add this all together at a price of about 3 dollars, and you've got a good game.

[b] A list for the lazy people [/b]

Pros
-Good story
-Endearing characters
-Good soundtrack
-Trading cards
-Cheap price 
-Funny achievements 

Cons
-Bland combat system
-Relatively short story, won't last as long as more expensive RPGs

I'd recommend it to anyone who likes RPGs with good stories, and have a few bucks to spare for it.

21663530.review: A dragon loli that can eat lies? Where do I sign the adoption papers?

21662419.review:
LiEat:
~~~~  

I guess everybody in their lifetime has managed to tell a couple of lies (or embellish the truth) here and there. Well, imagine you come across “Leo,” a caretaker, and “Efina,” a demon who is a lie detector, nourishing herself by eating lies. You would probably be in a rather awkward position, wouldn’t you say?

LiEat is a rich story /JRPG game where you play “Efina” and her caretaker in three very well written short stories (LiEat I, II and III). Leo is essentially a con artist who is selling information from one town to the next and keeps changing his name and appearance all the time. Efina was born from a dragon egg; she has the appearance a four year-old child but she is only two months old. She call Leo (Hal, Theo, Albert and god knows what) “Papa” (father) due to the fact that he has raised her since she hatched. 

In each location they visit, they will be faced with strange events, will investigate them and aim to find all the culprits. You will interact with interesting characters in each of the stories and even have the ability to read their bio’s at the end of each episode. I like that, as it really reinforces the thoughts behind all the characters in their journey. 
There is a combat phase, which is not the big aspect of this game; it is easy and provides you with a little bit of respite between the reading stages. 

The Pixel graphics lent the game a nostalgic feel, reminding me of playing on my colour Gameboy. Some people may find the low resolution a bit of an issue but all I can say is, do not worry about it. Great price point, only $2.99 for practically three games. No voice over in this game, however the soundtrack is good. 

Positives:
~~~~~~~ 

-	Three short and rich stories 
-	Interesting characters
-	Nice Pixel graphics
-	Achievements and trading cards

Negatives:
~~~~~~~~ 

-	Combat phase could have been better

LiEat series are well written and enjoyable to play (mostly reading).  Whether you already like this genre or have not yet been introduced to it, I recommend this series.

8/10

Key provided by developer/publisher for review purposes. Any opinions expressed are entirely my own!

21654661.review:
"Lies is like a box of chocolates. You never if they contain reasons or ugliness."

Made with the freeware WOLF RPG Maker and translated to english by vgperson, hits LiEat now the Steam store bundled up with all the three stories into one big game.

The game is divided into three stories taking inspiration from folklore and bedtime tales where you play as the dynamic duo  featuring a big time liar and con man Leo/Hal/Sid and his trusty young dragon companion Efi, wandering from town to town, gathering information and eating lies, Efi's dragon power. 
These games focus on a pecculiar form of detective work that could be envisioned as a fullblown franchise if it got developed even more, although cut low since it's by one guy. 

Bearing joyful plots and the use of it's inspirational sources, not only strikes LiEat on the writing of the world, but of the characters.
See, the two main protagonists here are on their own fleshed out quite good, dipping it's toes into terriories like on how being different, the xenophomic nature held up to a more leviated species, conflict of how to lie for a just cause and show that individuals either a different breed, line of work, interest and stances should't trace back to the majority because the lack of contexts of action. 
The true nature of lying as a crux can show how far these things can stretch before guilt manifests and swallow one whole on various levels, which is why it's interesting to see several of the characters makes up their own reasons by protecting somebody they love in almost all the instances of the series. LiEat is a nice spin on fronting, even enforcing truth in this by implementing that core element.


This isn't the only anchor point, but the distinguising artstyle using spesific coloring sets to separate the stories from one another along the semi minimal moe Final Fantasy-esque drawings displayed through either still images, animations or pixels. This isn't bad, as a matter of fact the creator must've known the doodliness works effectively here compared to his other art pieces (see KADOKAWA and v flower project).
Character designs are indeed good looking, however I cannot say it goes along with the environment cus the bits limit. It does however act lively, rich and blooming. Too bad this got killed due to the indoor enclosements in both II and III. 


Albeit an interesting detective fantasy RPG game, it's a working mess. 
I know from past experiences with the same engine that they're heavily scripted as well as ment to drive the plot from point to point exploration and dialogue exchangement (mainly notable in LiEat III). 
There's other things lacking like an options menu for resolutions and fullscreen, even though the F4 and F10  buttons would do that for you, but it would be nice to have a volume control incase you want to listen to something else than the great loopy BGM.

Speaking of sound, the tracks aren't the casual midi chiptunes pumped into a low functioning rpg game, but it sure hurts listening to the orchestra through on stereo. At some intervals, the sound just drops while there's tension in the dialogues or switches over to generic ass-ambience stock sounds.
Kills the mood.

Money is unecessary, since there's no vendors nor merchants to sell stuff to since the games stories are estimated 1-2 hours long, counting with grinding to simply slay everything with cheap tactics and become invunerable to "bosses" at the climaxes. 
Sporting a very nice hud for textboxes, the text itself appears out of center with additional quotation marks when characters speak. The weight on the text and the character avatar presented thus making it feeling overwhelmingly unscaled.

The game finishes in multiple endings, and whenever completed, the player will be treated with a gallery as a reward featuring short bios of characters, the BGM you can mess around with, and gallery frames of still images and animations from the story for viewing leisure.

Additional Steam bonuses like easy-to-get achievements and trading cards comes with, but if you want to experience the games without supporting Miwashiba's chibi gothic adventures, then see here: http://www.vgperson.com/games/lieat.htm

I'm not gonna lie, it's not a bad game overall spite the complaints, but goddamn is it a functional cluster. Give it a go if short games are your jam either of laziness or long working days.

I would highly recomend this, it's a quick fun story for only $3US

Bueno. en total, el muego me lo termine al 100% en 9 horas, un poco corto para ser un RPG, pero... ¿QUE IMPORTA?...
El juego, esta hecho con un engine tipo Rpg Maker, con unoas graficas muy hermosas con unos tonos de filtro de zules, naranjas y rosas muy lindos, la historia, muy buena, aunque como ya dije, muy corta, Manejas a Leo y a Efina, los cuales, viajan a 3 diferentes lugares (pues son 3 capitulos) a descubrir y resolver los misterios de los mismos. Al princio del juego, te daras cuenta que Efi, no solo es una niña, si no un dragon el cual, es de n tipo de especie que come mentiras, lo cual, hace un poco mas interesante y compleja la trama, hay tres finales, los cuales, son totalmente gratificantes.

LiEat, mas que ser un juego para hardcores de RPG's, es una muy buena aventura para jugadores nuevos en el genero, es muy facil, aunque divertido a la vez, las mismas graicas le dan vida al juego en general, y la musica ni se diga, totalmente hermosa :3

-Bunea historia
-Excelente musica
-Muy sencillo, disfrutable y casual
-El precio es bastante accesible (apenas 35 pesos mexicanos)
-Es totalmente rejugable, pues hay varios finales, mas los logros!

contras:

-Tal vez pudo ser un poco mas largo
-Hubiera sido de mucha ayuda incluir el idioma español, pues puuede que se le dificulte a algunas personas agarrarle el hilo a la trama.

Estos 2 puntos negativos, no son completamente malos, hay que entender que es un juego indie, por lo tanto, no tiene el dinero como para agregar mas idiomas o efectos.

De todos modos, es un indie rpg muy recomendable, y accesible para nuevos en el genero.

Gracias :3

标题的含义：Lie-Eat（嘘喰い，吃谎言）

一个擅长说谎的欺诈师，和一个能吃掉谎言的少（you）女的冒险。

三个短小却又引人深思的温馨童话。

都是关于爱与谎言的故事。很多时候为了保护自己所爱之人而制造谎言，然而这种善良并不一定能带来所希望的“爱”。谎言的漩涡可能带来灾祸，带来误解，带来憎恨。无论是说谎的人，还是被谎言欺骗的人，都很可能被卷进悲剧的螺旋。

以走剧情为主，有少许解谜和战斗成分，但丝毫没有难度。三部曲总共3个小时左右就可以通关。

讲道理，强烈推荐这部作品，尤其是幼女控更是不能错过。

21593455.review:
LiEat is just lovely from beginning to end.

Though it's labeled as RPG, it plays more like a visual novel, laying heavy focus on the story and containing only rudimentary elements of traditional JRPG. It's not hard to find the few hidden items and it's harder to lose the battles than to win them. That being said, the game is still quite enjoyable since it's really relaxing but still gives you the feeling you actually have to do something to progess instead of just clicking and sometimes making a choice like most visual novels.

The story is divided into three arcs each considered their own game, making it a trilogy. While it certainly doesn't deliver the most depth, the lovely characters manage to pull you into their world and make you want to unweave the mysteries and see the solving. There are multiple endings to each arc based on your decisions and the key parts of the story are beautifully illustrated/animated. 

Another part about the game that really stuck out to me was the music. Every arc has it's own set of 10 themes and most of them became stuck in my head at first listen. Not only is the soundtrack diverse and catchy, it's also always perfectly fitting the current mood, enhancing the atmosphere in every situation.

Each arc of the LiEat trilogy takes about 1-2 hours depending on how fast you read and how meticulous you search for hidden stuff. While I do wish there was a little more focus on the RPG elements, I enjoyed the game a lot and can only recommend it. 3€ is 1€ per arc, which I think is more than fair.

21590684.review:
First review, bare with me.

LiEat is a very charming game that is simple, yet engaging in its own way. It's amazing how much enjoyment you can get out of something short, and for me, the price is spot on for what its worth. I have completed 2 out of the 3 story arches, and I have to say the first 2 were pretty fun.

If you want a short, simple, yet enjoyable game to play, I would consider picking this up!

21589966.review:
A sweet, simple story about humans, dragons, and lies.

Don't get this game if you're looking for an RPG. The RPG combat elements are really only there to help lend a sense of player involvement in the story, and, as crappy as they honestly are, they serve their purpose well enough. The main appeal here is story, and let me tell you, it's quite good.

The game itself is very mystery-focused, and you'll find yourself feeling sort of like a detective as you try to uncover what's happening and which characters are the culprits of various crimes in each of the three episodes. While the mysteries are nothing mind-bogglingly ingenious, and it can be unclear at times where you need to go, they're generally well put together and suit the overarching theme of the game very well.

The characters are truly charming, especially the two main characters, who (amusingly) kind of serve as foils to each other. Learning more about them through their interactions with each other and the other characters is highly engaging, and I found myself surprisingly invested in their fates by the time the game's ending rolled around, which might I mention actually varies depending on your actions, and has the potential to CRUSH YOUR SOUL like it did mine.

[b]TL;DR - [/b]
Is it perfect? No.
But saying it's not worth playing would make me a great big liar.

Wow. That's the only word coming to mind, at first I bought this, being the only thought of "RPG maker, I found some great indie games in this game maker." So I payed some birthday money... and

Was introduced to a small girl and a caring, theiving father. Each dialogue, each person I talked to kept cringing me to want more and seek out what I truly wanted out of this game, however each time I did my mind just kept being answered and rewarded, the game was just so intreguing. Finally after 6 hours I beat each and every puzzle, took on every part of the corruption and fought my way to find the last amount, I came across such a intreguing ending and just... wanted more.
The game was only released friday, but I couldn't hold myself to buy this for my boyfriend (And steal his trading cards~!) and share this experience.
The puzzles themselves were odd, they had a plain sight and odd taste, but kept me going.
The music was one of my favorites, every sound track matched perfectly and I feel like I could download each indevidual one and listen for hours.
Finally, the characters, art, and dialogue were by far the best i have ever seen. Being that this was made in such a simple engine, i found myself looking at cutscenes and cutesy art in the view of a small child, everything I looked at I just felt joyful taking in each sprite. I.. wanted more.

Please, if anyone reads this, I would love if anyone could point me at a game like this one, possibly a part IV or above, i just... want more.

Thanks for your time, and developers, keep creating such great games!!

For the cheap price, the game worth it. The game is story-heavy, while the battles are just a tool to progress. The focus is talking to NPCs and searching around. The combat is as simple as it gets: Attack, Magic, Items, Do Nothing. To get the most out of this game, you really need to pay attention to the dialogue.

The game is split up into three separate chapters, so whatever level you were in Chapter 1, you start from the beginning in Chapter 2. But that's not a bad thing, since the monsters aren't a challange in the first place. The game runs smooth, with no hiccups, aside from the text glitch, but that's easy fix. The artstyle feels handdrawn, with little animations here and there that are very nice. The music isn' amazing, but it fits with the atmosphere, and I would buy a digital soundtrack & artbook if they ever released it.

21556211.review:
"LiEat" is a relatively short game that includes three "episodes" which include different mysteries that have to be solved by the two main characters. I love these two characters and loved how they were put togeather and why they were (No Spoilers Here ;) ) Each episode is about 30 minutes to an hour long and can be difficult to solve some of the puzzles for people who are new to puzzles in games or are terrible with puzzles (Like Me). The story of the whole series becomes pretty straightforward but still gives a few clues, hints, or secrets to reveal about the characters' backgrounds or part of the story.

The downside to this game is that their are not a lot of environments. For example, the first episode takes place in a single town and a small section outside the enterance. This also includes a single alley way that had more to do with the story than more than half of the houses in the town that had less than five citizens. The rest of the episodes are relatively the same when it comes to the number of environments and characters.

Overall, this game is one of the cutest RPGs that I have ever played the downside to this game is that it does not include a lot of content which is its downside. However, if you are looking for a short, little RPG, this game would be perfect for you.

Plot: 8
Characters: 8
Character Development: 6
Environment: 8

Overall: 7.5

LiEat proves a unique experience by mashing up comedy, horror, creepiness, and surreal at the same time.
Obviously, the cover of the game is making you think "Wow, this is a fanservicey game. Just another porn game on Steam." Nothing NSFW at all, nothing. I know a few weeaboos on my friends list who scour through games like these looking for NSFW dialog, but there's nothing.

21522974.review:
LiEat is a relatively short JRPG which includes three different chapters, both approximately around 1 hour long (if you're not speeding through the text and really tryin to look into every nook or cranny). If you're a fan of such games as Ib, The Witch's House, Alice Mare then LiEat is probably a game meant for you. Although it isn't quite horror oriented other than for mild body horror, it is a very story-driven game, which focuses on two main characters, a con artist named who goes by many names and a dragon girl named Efina.

There are 30 Steam achievements for this game, most of which can be found on your first playthrough if you're looking everywhere and talking to each character. Such dedication is rewarded with not only more information about our main characters and their history, but also different items, some of which make our heroes nigh impossible to defeat. As it might be evident of my high play time I sought out all achievements and replayed each chapter at least 30 times due to just wanting to explore on my own and uncover secrets without helpful guidances. However, getting the last few achievements proved to be quite difficult, so if you get stuck, be sure to look up vgperson's site, who translated this game, along with many other.

The graphics are adorable and the pixel portraits are very nicely done, so those who enjoy 2D pixelated graphics will definitely enjoy the game. The soundtrack is nice as well, it never seemed to get on my nerves or annoy me after listening to the music for hours upon hours. LiEat knows how to create atmosphere, whether it is to make things silly or horrifyingly dreadful, something which can definitely be experienced throughout the chapters, especially in the last one.

[b]TL:DR;[/b] If we want to go by Funhaus Spoole's view on the worth of games, which is 1 Dollar 1 Hour, aka if you pay one dollar that equals one hour of gameplay, then buying LiEat gives you more than enough content over 3 hours. As you can see I've gotten good 7 hours from this game just trying to complete it and get all of the achievements.

Honestly, the game is just three dollars and if you really enjoy story-driven 2D games, LiEat is definitely for you.

21516670.review:
Don't let the "Loli" Steam banner fool you. 

This isn't a JRPG that panders to the Loli-crowd. Instead, I'll hazard to say that LiEat (I, II, and III) doesn't pander at all. Instead, the developer focused on bringing us a solid and well written story. The story itself isn't anything amazing, and often, the mysteries solve themselves in the first act. However, what really kept it interesting were the characters. The characters are endearing, mysterious, and funny.

The game includes 3 Chapters. Each has multiple endings. The first two chapters each took me about 1.5 hours, and the last one stumped me for a bit when I couldn't get the Good Ending.

The BGM are great and sets the mood as well. 

I highly recommend this to anyone looking to play a short game with memorable characters. Just don't expect this game to last you any more than 5 hours tops.

EDIT: Also, any achievement that includes Ranma 1/2 is gold in my book: Happosai~!

21488038.review:
If you like indie story-based RPG games, I'd highly reccomend trying out LiEat. It's a bit of a short game, only taking me about two hours to complete each of the games, but with the small price as much is to be expected. It can be at time creepy, but it's not really a horror game, so if you're looking for your usual RPGMaker Horror game, you won't exactly be crapping your pants every other scene, if that means anything to you.

I think that this is one of those games where saying anything huge about the story is something of a spoiler, but to generalize it, the story follows a stoic young man and a happy dragon-girl that he come across not long before the first game, and each of the games follow the same pair, despite physical properties somewhat shifting. It's a bit odd, if the concept interests you even slightly, though, I think you won't be disappointed.

Of course, you probably don't need me to spell it out to you, but if you're looking for strong gameplay, you should look elsewhere. The normal battles all pretty much play out the same, and the bosses only require an ever-so-slight amount of thought to actually beat. This isn't a gameplay based game, of course, this is only there to add the experience slightly.

Basically, do you like story games? If yes, and you have a three bucks lying around (And really, who doesn't?), then I highly reccomend giving this game a try. If you're cold and heartless, a free version of the three games can be found on it's website, but it's obvious that Miwashiba worked very hard on this game, so don't be stingy and just give up the pocket change, believe me, it's worth it.

21487326.review:
Every now and then a game comes along as something more of an experience worth being a part of rather than something to 'beat.' LiEat falls squarely in that realm with it's low asking price and unique charm. 

The story isn't anything complicated that you'll need to sit and think about, and there isn't any powergaming to worry about. LiEat simply exists as a platform to tell a unique story that I think many people would get some joy out of. 

There are minor RPG elements in the game, but really more than anything they only exist to carry the story to it's conclusion. There are multiple endings to the chapters, and some extra achievements and scenes to unlock if you're a bit of a completionist. In the end, however, LiEat is something worth taking your time with and simply enjoying rather than looking for the quickest way to get to the next stage.

The spritework and CG art are absolutely phenomenal, and the small bits of animation here and there breath a lot of life into the characters and the world around them. The music only further adds to this. 

All in all go into LiEat with an open mind. I think most people will find it worth their time to play. It's one of those games where I'll look back on it and fondly remember it for standing out as something unique in my library, and not something that I simply 'finished'.

21486231.review:
LiEat is a collection of three originally freeware short story-telling RPG made by △○□× (hereon Miwashiba) using Wolf RPG Editor, not too different from other story-telling experiences like Mogeko Castle.

Since the story is the focus of the games, might as well talk about them. Each individual title is a mystery-horror set in a fantastical world where anthropomorphized animals and humans live. Aside from this there exist the rare "dragon" who are human in appearance but have horns and the ability to use magical powers. You take control of the party of the main character who changes his name and appearance in every game and her small lie-eating dragon Efina. Each game takes place in a different small location and presents a different situation and presents a different "mystery" to our characters with small touches of horror. The main character is a con man who uses Efina to get information out of people and then use it to sell to interested parties among other frauds, while Efina is just an almost newborn dragon who follows the main character everywhere. In each story we meet a colorful cast of characters, including some recurring ones that will shed some light into our main character's enigmatic past. While each story is self-conclusive and mostly unrelated to previous one playing in order is advised.

The gameplay is minimal in LiEat, there are RPG battles every now and then but they are pathetically easy and almost impossible to lose. You get a large stock of healing items found throughout the map and three sets of equipment (stronger weapons, armor and overpowered weapons), nothing carries over from one game to another but every equipment and item is laughably easy to obtain. There are multiple endings (bad, neutral and good/true) in each game with varying requisites but they don't add a lot of replayability since the requirements are simple and usually involve following a set of events in a certain order. At the end of each game you can access a bonus room with galleries, music player and character info which is nice. The games are REALLY short too, each story lasts roughly 45 minutes so the entire trilogy can be beat in 2-3 hours.

The game sports a pretty distinctive art style in both pixel art and event images. Each game has a motif color (red, blue and gold respectively) and character designs are pretty charming and cute. LiEat I&II have been updated to match the third game and now also have short animated cutscenes at key events. The music is nice, nothing that I would listen to outside of the game but suits the mood and is nice to hum while playing.

LiEat is not the biggest masterpiece of story telling but I found each story charming and fascinating on their own. The freeware versions of each game are still available for download in many languages, so paying for the Steam version is pretty much just supporting the authors and getting the knick-knacks of achievements and trading cards. At the low price of $3 I found this to be acceptable and bought without regrets.

if you don't want to waste time fighting then pick up the overpowered weapons hidden somewhere in the one stage you get per game to jump your attack from say 5 to 450! no grinding or anything so that part made me think of it as closer to a visual novel then a JRPG

This is 3 games or episodes in one package. Lieat 1, 2 and 3 so it's paying $1 per episode. game time is between 30 minutes to 1 hour for each.

Art work is nice , the music is nice but the game's strongest point is the dialogue.

Shame that the story-line wasn't better to make it a more rounded game but as of now, it's a fun little game that's short and sweet.

21470729.review:
How much is a smile worth?

LiEat is a non-linear title with mild horror themes. It's a "story-based" game, which is to say, the "game" aspect is merely a vehicle for literally everything else. It's technically a Japanese-style RPG, but the battles are a mere formality; combat rarely amounts to more than holding down the Confirm key until they end, with very little strategy except in rare situations, and even those can be circumvented entirely if you're of the mind and find the right items. I'm normally averse to these sorts of titles, a firm believer that a game that doesn't focus at least in part on its gameplay is a waste of a game, but LiEat appropriately made a liar out of me, and my annoyance with that fact is matched only by my gladness at being wrong.

I didn't quite know what to expect when getting into this one, but I can say that whatever I could have guessed it was would've been wrong with room to spare; LiEat is surreal, strange, sometimes creepy, sometimes silly, yet consistently, if I have to admit it, charming. Developer Miwashiba uses each "game" to tell a tale of the ongoing travels of a humanoid dragon child who subsists off of the lies of the others, and her cynical, conniving, big fat liar of a caretaker, as they travel the land in search of the world's most valuable commodity: information. Our liar's muddy morality and views on the world are intriguing, and his foil is one of the most legitimately delightful child characters in any work of fiction I've encountered; rather than being smarter or tougher than you could legitimately expect her to be, she's reactive, naive, and even a little dense, yet without being grating, and while she's hyper-idealized, I'm willing to bet you're not going to care. I swear that if I didn't know my own kid wouldn't be the most insufferable thing ever just to spite me, I'd want one just for the off chance it turned out something like her.

This is all conveyed well by translator and localizer vgperson's mostly enjoyable interpretation of the games' quirky dialogue, the writing of which is consistently engaging and thematic. Like its plot, the original score is unusual, yet enjoyable, the setting is foreboding, yet inviting, the characters are mysterious and enigmatic -- save for one mentioned above  --  and the plot isn't fully explained. Rather than fall prey to being confusing as a result, though, the whole thing ends up interesting, and every interaction teaches you more about LiEat's strange world and its inhabitants, which is impressive given that each of the three extremely short games take place in one area each. There's little exploration, no adventuring, and no questing; you're presented with a self-contained mystery to solve, and the game is over as soon as the case is closed. Each game features at least one bad ending, and one "real" ending, and after the latter, you either move onto the next game after a visit to a gallery room, or run out of games.

The result is probably unlike anything you've come across, even among the independent scene. There's no soapbox for it to climb upon, no deep, hidden meaning for people to form a cult around and talk down to others over, no quirky fetishes to pander to, and no nerd culture to propagate; it's just a story of two people and the people they run into, but it was enough to get a couple legitimate laughs out joy out of this grouchy old fart, and again, this isn't even my kind of game.

So how much is a smile worth? Turns out the best ones are free, but three dollars was a fair price, too.

I'd be lying if I said I didn't think that if you've read this far, you'll agree.

* Note that I'd previously played this game from an alternative source, which is why my total time played is low as of this writing.

39182076.review:
I've only found the strength for the first of the three parts, so here it goes:

LiEat is a slightly cuter than average RPG-maker game. I see a lot of praise for the music and the visuals and I have no idea what that's all about as it all feels fairly standard. As usual for these games, combat is atrocious and in LiEat it's also not even remotely challenging. The game itself is superlinear and consists only of you going around interacting with people and stuff to advance the story. It's basically simplified down to where it becomes a visual novel, but where visual novels start with an intriguing premise, this one just seems cobbled together to seem quirky enough for whoever-the-target-audience-for-this-sort-of-thing-is because it definitely left me with a feeling of "what the hell did I just play"and even more so of "why the hell did I play this for so long"?

I apologize in advance if parts 2/3 are masterpieces to be cherished by future generations, because I can't even think of continuing after the boredom I endured. Every minute felt like at least five.

3/10

39034019.review:
LiEat is a great game. 
I pretty much liked most of its content. The art is really cute, the songs fit the scenarios well and
how each adventure was divided by chapters was nice too.

Only a few characters stand out, most of them felt a bit dull. 
It's a short gameplay, so there wasn't much time spent in character development, even though the time spent in it was well used.

The only other thing that bothered me was how all fights offered no challenge. It's almost impossible to lose unintentionally. It could be a little challenging if you weren't able to rest every single time and the monsters weren't so weak.

In short

Pros
Art 10/10
Story 8/10
Music 10/10
Atmosphere 8/10

Cons
Character development 7/10 (Papa and Efina 9/10)
Combat system 5/10
NO MAIN CHARACTERS BADGES BESIDES THE FOIL 1/10

8/10 will play again

39001417.review:
Surprisingly good game. I got it from a Humble Bundle deal and almost gave it away.

The final chapter neatly wraps up questions about each important character and their pasts there's a nice combination of humor and grim between plots. The artwork is beautiful and the sound effects are perfect but the music sometimes gets a little annoying. It's a really short game that's a little too easy to win but satisfying nonetheless. Despite the brevity of the game, there is good depth for each character introduced. 

Didn't like arrow key control. Window size was too small and no option menu. Little to no instruction on control: space, enter, or z to interact; escape key to go back; and arrow keys to walk instead of wasd. A few minor plotholes.

38999486.review:
Bought in a Humble Bundle for $1.
[h1]Honest first impressions as I play.[/h1]

Started LiEat,
Was 1/10th the Screensize.
After figuring how to maximize the Window, I was locked on 15 FPS, through multiple relaunches until it finially decided to give me 60.
Continued another 15seconds and was prompted with a Control issue after needing to access a Door, I'm not interested in spamming all the letters, numbers and F1's in order to find the relevant keybinds.

It's at this point I decided to alt-tab to write the first portion of the review, as I'm already Negative Nelly towards it.
Continuing back to the game from my Dual Monitor set-up and it's decided to blackscreen.
It's bypassable with ease by just clicking the window in your taskbar.

It gives off a Pokemon Yellow sort of atmosphere.
All the Houses are copy pasted, even the insides. I'm often checking all the copy-pasted houses for NPC's continuously to progress the story in this small town.
You've got a Pikachu Anime girl following you, it appears the protagonist is the obnoxious Male leading around the town.

Just fought a Demon in the Town.
I can safely assume our characters are some sort of Demon Hunters that fight them regularly as there was no dialogue meant for the player to understand the situation, or any surprise from our Characters fighting a random enemy in the peaceful town.

After Saving the game for the first time, once again LiEat has decided to lock me in 15 fps again, it's at this 10 minute point that the Game has become a burden
Searching for a solution, it turns out the F5 key cycles through different FrameSkip options, this is something I would of hit earlier in the game originally when figuring out how to Fullscreen, as well as the Basic control schemes.

Continuing further in the game and the introduction of "Lies" comes into the Story, they're the so called Demons I've seen (they personally shouldn't of been introduced until this portion was explained)
